blocks.text: Forced, otherwise Q X P mates.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 1. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt

blocks.text: 2. Q - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         3. B x P mate.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Q - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         3. B x P mate.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 14.--The same type of combination occurs in a more complicated form in the following position. {22}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Q - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         3. B x P mate.

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Q - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         3. B x P mate.

blocks.text: 1. B x Kt                 Q x B.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 1. B x Kt                 Q x B.

blocks.text: If ...B x Kt; Q - B 3 threatens mate, and therefore wins the Q, which is already attacked.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 1. B x Kt                 Q x B.

blocks.text: 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 15.--A very frequent type of combination is shown in the following position.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.

blocks.text: [Illustration] {23}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.

blocks.text: Here White is the exchange and a Pawn behind, but he can win quickly thus: 1 B x P ch, K x B. (If 1...K - R 1; 2 Q - K R 5, P - K Kt 3; 3 Q - R 6, and wins.)
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.

blocks.text: 2 Q - R 5 ch, K - Kt 1; 3 Kt - Kt 5, and Black cannot stop mate at K R 7 except by sacrificing the Queen by Q - K 5, which would leave White with a Q for a R.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 16.--This same type of combination is seen in a more complicated form in the following position.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.

blocks.text: White proceeds as follows: 1 Kt x Kt ch (this clears the line for the B); B x Kt (to stop the Kt from moving to Kt 5 after the sacrifice of the B); 2 R x B, Kt x R best; 3 B x P ch, K x B. (If 3..K - R 1; 4 Q - R 5, P - K Kt 3; 5 B x P ch, K - Kt 2; 6 Q - R 7 ch, K - B 3; 7 P - Kt 5 ch, K - K 3; 8 B x P ch, R x B; 9 Q - K 4 mate.) 4 Q - R 5 ch, K - Kt 1; 5 Kt - Kt 5, R - B 1; {24} 6 Q - R 7 ch, K - B 1; 7 Q - R 8 ch, Kt - Kt 1; 8 Kt - R 7 ch, K - K 2; 9 R - K 1 ch, K - Q 1; 10 Q x Kt mate.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.

blocks.text: This combination is rather long and has many variations, therefore a beginner will hardly be able to fathom it; but, knowing the type of combination, he might under similar circumstances undertake and carry out a brilliant attack which he would otherwise never think of. It will be seen that all the combinations shown have for a foundation the proper co-ordination of the pieces, which have all been brought to bear against a weak point.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.
EXAMPLE 13. > 2. Kt - B 6 ch            P x Kt         3. R - Kt 3 ch            K - R 1         4. B x P mate.

blocks.text: 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: Before going on to the general principles of the openings, it is advisable to give the student an idea of the proper relative value of the pieces. There is no complete and accurate table for all of them, and the only thing to do is to compare the pieces separately.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: For all general theoretical purposes the Bishop and the Knight have to be considered as of the same value, though it is my opinion that the Bishop will prove the more valuable piece in most cases; and it is well known that two Bishops are almost always better than two Knights.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: The Bishop will be stronger against Pawns than the Knight, and in
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 11/95
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: combination with Pawns will also be stronger against the Rook than the Knight will be. {25}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: A Bishop and a Rook are also stronger than a Knight and a Rook, but a Queen and a Knight may be stronger than a Queen and a Bishop.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: A Bishop will often be worth more than three Pawns, but a Knight very seldom so, and may even not be worth so much.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: A Rook will be worth a Knight and two Pawns, or a Bishop and two Pawns, but, as said before, the Bishop will be a better piece against the Rook.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: Two Rooks are slightly stronger than a Queen. They are slightly weaker than two Knights and a Bishop, and a little more so than two Bishops and a Knight. The power of the Knight decreases as the pieces are changed off. The power of the Rook, on the contrary, increases.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: The King, a purely _defensive_ piece throughout the middle-game, becomes an _offensive_ piece once all the pieces are off the board, and sometimes even when there are one or two minor pieces left. The handling of the King becomes of paramount importance once the end-game stage is reached.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES
EXAMPLE 13. > 5. RELATIVE VALUE OF THE PIECES

blocks.text: 6. GENERAL STRATEGY OF THE OPENING
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 6. GENERAL STRATEGY OF THE OPENING

blocks.text: The main thing is to _develop the pieces quickly_. Get them into play as fast as you can.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 6. GENERAL STRATEGY OF THE OPENING

blocks.text: From the outset two moves, 1 P - K 4  or 1 P - Q 4, open up lines for the Queen and a Bishop. Therefore, theoretically one of these two moves must be the best, as no other first move accomplishes so much. {26}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 6. GENERAL STRATEGY OF THE OPENING

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 17.--Suppose we begin:
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 6. GENERAL STRATEGY OF THE OPENING

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3

blocks.text: This is both an attacking and a developing move. Black can now either reply with the identical move or play
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3
EXAMPLE 13. > 2. ........               Kt - Q B 3

blocks.text: This developing move at the same time defends the King's Pawn.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 2. ........               Kt - Q B 3

blocks.text: 3. Kt - B 3               Kt - B 3
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 3. Kt - B 3               Kt - B 3

blocks.text: These moves are of a purely developing nature.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 3. Kt - B 3               Kt - B 3

blocks.text: 4. B - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 4. B - Kt 5

blocks.text: _It is generally advisable not to bring this Bishop out until one Knight is out_, preferably the King's Knight. The Bishop could also have been played to B 4, but it is advisable whenever possible to combine development and attack.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 4. B - Kt 5

blocks.text: Black replies in the same manner, threatening a possible exchange of Bishop for Knight with Kt x P to follow.
5. O - O
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. O - O

blocks.text: an indirect way of preventing 5...B x Kt, which more experience or study will show to be bad. At the same time _the Rook is brought into action in the centre, a very important point_. {27}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 5. O - O

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 12/95
Black follows the same line of reasoning.
6. P - Q 3                P - Q 3
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 6. P - Q 3                P - Q 3

blocks.text: These moves have a two-fold object, viz.: to protect the King's Pawn and to open the diagonal for the development of the Queen's Bishop.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 6. P - Q 3                P - Q 3

blocks.text: 7. B - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 7. B - Kt 5

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 7. B - Kt 5

blocks.text: A very powerful move, which brings us to the middle-game stage, as there is already in view a combination to win quickly by Kt - Q 5. This threat makes it impossible for Black to continue the same course. (There is a long analysis showing that Black should lose if he also plays B - Kt 5.) He is now forced to play 7...B x Kt, as experience has shown, thus bringing up to notice three things.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 7. B - Kt 5

blocks.text: First, the complete development of the opening has taken only seven moves. (This varies up to ten or twelve moves in some very exceptional cases. As a rule, eight should be enough.) Second, Black has {28} been compelled to exchange a Bishop for a Knight, but as a compensation he has isolated White's Q R P and doubled a Pawn. (This, at such an early stage of the game, is rather an advantage for White, as the Pawn is doubled towards the centre of the board.) Third, White by the exchange brings up a Pawn to control the square Q 4, puts Black on the defensive, as experience will show, and thus keeps _the initiative_, an unquestionable advantage.[1]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 7. B - Kt 5

blocks.text: The strategical principles expounded above are the same for all the openings, only their tactical application varies according to the circumstances.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 7. B - Kt 5

blocks.text: Before proceeding further I wish to lay stress on the following point which the student should bear in mind.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 7. B - Kt 5

blocks.text: _Before development has been completed no piece should be moved more than once, unless it is essential in order to obtain either material advantage or to secure freedom of action._
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 7. B - Kt 5

blocks.text: The beginner would do well to remember this, as well as what has already been stated: viz., _bring out the Knights before bringing out the Bishops_.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 7. B - Kt 5
EXAMPLE 13. > 7. B - Kt 5

blocks.text: 7. CONTROL OF THE CENTRE
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 7. CONTROL OF THE CENTRE

blocks.text: The four squares, K 4 and Q 4 on each side respectively, are the centre squares, and control of these squares is called control of the centre. _The control of the centre is of great importance._ No violent attack can succeed without controlling at least two of these {29} squares, and possibly three. Many a manoeuvre in the opening has for its sole object the control of the centre, which invariably ensures the initiative. It is well always to bear this in mind, since it will often be the reason of a series of moves which could not otherwise be properly understood. As this book progresses I shall dwell more fully on these different points. At present I shall devote some time to openings taken at random and explain the moves according to general principles. The student will in that way train his mind in the proper direction, and will thus have less trouble in finding a way out when confronted with a new and difficult situation.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 13. > 7. CONTROL OF THE CENTRE

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 18.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 18.

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             P - Q 3
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 18. > 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             P - Q 3

blocks.text: A timid move. Black assumes a defensive attitude at once. On principle the move is wrong. In the openings, whenever possible, _pieces should be moved in preference to Pawns_.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 18. > 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             P - Q 3

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 18. > 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             P - Q 3

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 13/95
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 18. > 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             P - Q 3
EXAMPLE 18. > 3. P - Q 4

blocks.text: White takes the offensive immediately and strives to control the centre so as to have ample room to deploy his forces.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 18. > 3. P - Q 4

blocks.text: Black does not wish to relinquish the centre and also prefers the text move to Kt - Q B 3, which would be the more natural square for the Kt. But on {30} principle the move is wrong, because it blocks the action of the Queen's Bishop, and instead of facilitating the action of Black's pieces, tends, on the contrary, to cramp them.
4. B - Q B 4              P - K R 3
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 18. > 4. B - Q B 4              P - K R 3

blocks.text: Black is forced to pay the penalty of his previous move. Such a move on Black's part condemns by itself any form of opening that makes it necessary. White threatened Kt - Kt 5 and Black could not stop it with 4...B - K 2, because of 5 P x P, Kt x P (if 5...P x P, 6 Q - Q 5); 6 Kt x Kt, P x Kt; 7 Q - R 5, and White wins a Pawn and has besides a perfectly safe position.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 18. > 4. B - Q B 4              P - K R 3

blocks.text: 5. Kt - B 3               K Kt - B 3         6. B - K 3                B - K 2         7. Q - K 2
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 18. > 5. Kt - B 3               K Kt - B 3         6. B - K 3                B - K 2         7. Q - K 2

blocks.text: It should be noticed that White does not Castle yet. The reason is that he wants to deploy his forces first, and through the last move force Black to play P - Q B 3 to make room for the Queen as White threatens R - Q 1, to be followed by P x P. Black's other alternatives would finally force him to play P x P, thus abandoning the centre to White.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 18. > 5. Kt - B 3               K Kt - B 3         6. B - K 3                B - K 2         7. Q - K 2

blocks.text: With this last move White completes his development, while Black is evidently somewhat hampered. A simple examination will suffice to show that White's position {31} is unassailable. There are no weak spots in his armour, and his pieces are ready for any manoeuvre that he may wish to carry out in order to begin the attack on the enemy's position. The student should carefully study this example. It will show him that it is sometimes convenient to delay Castling. I have given the moves as they come to my mind without following any standard book on openings. Whether the moves given by me agree or not with the standard works, I do not know, but at the present stage of this book it is not convenient to enter into discussions of mere technicalities which the student will be able to understand when he has become more proficient.
EXAMPLE 19.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19.

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             P - Q 3         3. P - Q 4                B - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19.

blocks.text: A bad move, which violates one of the principles set down, according to which at least one Knight should be developed before the Bishops are brought out, and also because it exchanges a Bishop for a Knight, which in the opening is generally bad, unless there is some compensation.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19.

blocks.text: 4. P x P                  B x Kt
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 4. P x P                  B x Kt

blocks.text: 4...P x P loses a Pawn.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 4. P x P                  B x Kt

blocks.text: 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3

blocks.text: If Kt - B 3; Q - Q Kt 3 wins a Pawn.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 14/95
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3

blocks.text: {32} /*    7. Q - Q Kt 3 P - Q Kt 3    8. Kt - B 3 P - Q B 3 */
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3

blocks.text: To prevent Kt - Q 5.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3

blocks.text: Black, however, has no pieces out except his Queen, and White, with a Bishop and a Knight already developed, has a chance of obtaining an advantage quickly by playing Kt - Q 5 anyway. The student is left to work out the many variations arising from this position.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3

blocks.text: These examples will show the practical application of the principles previously enunciated. The student is warned against playing Pawns in preference to pieces at the beginning of the game, especially P - K R 3 and P - Q R 3, which are moves very commonly indulged in by beginners.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3
EXAMPLE 19. > 5. Q x B                  P x P         6. B - Q B 4              Q - B 3

blocks.text: 8. TRAPS
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 8. TRAPS

blocks.text: I shall now give a few positions or traps to be avoided in the openings, and in which (practice has shown) beginners are often caught. {33}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 19. > 8. TRAPS

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 20.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 20.

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 20.

blocks.text: White plays:
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 20.

blocks.text: 1. P x P                  Kt x P
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 20. > 1. P x P                  Kt x P

blocks.text: Black should have recaptured with the Pawn.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 20. > 1. P x P                  Kt x P

blocks.text: 2. Kt x Kt                B x Q         3. B x P ch               K - K 2         4. Kt - Q 5 mate.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 20. > 2. Kt x Kt                B x Q         3. B x P ch               K - K 2         4. Kt - Q 5 mate.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 21.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 21.

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 21.

blocks.text: {34} Black, having the move, should play P - K 3. But suppose he plays Kt - K B 3 instead, then comes--
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 21.

blocks.text: 1. B x P ch
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 21. > 1. B x P ch

blocks.text: Kt - K 5 would also give White the advantage, the threat being of course if B x Q; 2 B x P mate. Nor does B - R 5 help matters, because of 2 Q x B, 1... B - K 3 leaves Black with the inferior position. But White's move in the text secures an immediate material advantage, and the beginner at any rate should never miss such an opportunity for the sake of a speculative advantage in position.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 21. > 1. B x P ch

blocks.text: 1. ........               K x B         2. Kt - K 5 ch            K moves         3. Kt x B
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 21. > 1. ........               K x B         2. Kt - K 5 ch            K moves         3. Kt x B

blocks.text: and White has won a Pawn besides having the better position.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 21. > 1. ........               K x B         2. Kt - K 5 ch            K moves         3. Kt x B

blocks.text: There are a good many other traps--in fact, there is a book written on traps on the chess board; but the type given above is the most common of all.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 21. > 1. ........               K x B         2. Kt - K 5 ch            K moves         3. Kt x B
EXAMPLE 21. > 1. ........               K x B         2. Kt - K 5 ch            K moves         3. Kt x B
EXAMPLE 21. > 1. ........               K x B         2. Kt - K 5 ch            K moves         3. Kt x B

blocks.text: CHAPTER II
blocks.section_path: CHAPTER II

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: CHAPTER II

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 15/95
blocks.section_path: CHAPTER II

blocks.text: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY

blocks.text: We shall now go back to the endings in search of a few more principles, then again to the middle-game, and finally to the openings once more, so that the advance may not only be gradual but homogeneous. In this way the foundation on which we expect to build the structure will be firm and solid.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY

blocks.text: 9. A CARDINAL PRINCIPLE
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 9. A CARDINAL PRINCIPLE

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 9. A CARDINAL PRINCIPLE

blocks.text: In the position shown above, White can draw by playing P - Kt 4 according to the general rule that governs such cases, i.e. _to advance the Pawn that is free from opposition_. But suppose that White, either because he does not know this principle or because he {36} does not, in this case, sufficiently appreciate the value of its application; suppose, we say, that he plays 1 P - Q R 4. Then Black can win by playing 1... P - Q R 4, applying one of the cardinal principles of the high strategy of chess--
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 9. A CARDINAL PRINCIPLE

blocks.text: _A unit that holds two._
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 9. A CARDINAL PRINCIPLE > _A unit that holds two._

blocks.text: In this case one Pawn would hold two of the opponent's Pawns. The student cannot lay too much stress on this principle. It can be applied in many ways, and it constitutes one of the principal weapons in the hands of a master.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 9. A CARDINAL PRINCIPLE > _A unit that holds two._

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 22.--The example given should be sufficient proof. We give a few moves of the main variation:--
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 9. A CARDINAL PRINCIPLE > _A unit that holds two._

blocks.text: 1. P - R 4                P - Q R 4         2. K - Kt 2               K - B 5             (Best; see why.)         3. P - Kt 4               P x P             (Best.)         4. P - R 5                P - Kt 6         5. P - R 6                P - Kt 7         6. P - R 7                P - Kt 8 (Q)         7. P - R 8 (Q)            Q - K 5 ch         8. Q x Q                  K x Q
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 9. A CARDINAL PRINCIPLE > _A unit that holds two._

blocks.text: This brings the game to a position which is won by Black, and which constitutes one of the classical endings of King and Pawns. I shall try to explain the guiding idea of it to those not familiar with it. {37}
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 9. A CARDINAL PRINCIPLE > _A unit that holds two._
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 9. A CARDINAL PRINCIPLE > _A unit that holds two._

blocks.text: 10. A CLASSICAL ENDING
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 10. A CLASSICAL ENDING

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 10. A CLASSICAL ENDING

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 23.--In this position White's best line of defence consists in keeping his Pawn where it stands at R 2. As soon as the Pawn is advanced it becomes easier for Black to win. On the other hand, Black's plan to win (supposing that White does not advance his Pawn) may be divided into three parts. The first part will be to get his King to K R 6, at the same time keeping intact the position of his Pawns. (This is all important, since, in order to win the game, it is essential at the end that Black may be able to advance his rearmost Pawn one or two squares according to the position of the White King.)
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 10. A CLASSICAL ENDING

blocks.text: 1. K - Kt 3               K - K 6         2. K - Kt 2
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Kt 3               K - K 6         2. K - Kt 2

blocks.text: If 2 K - Kt 4, K - B 7; 3 P - R 4, P - Kt 3 will win. {38}
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Kt 3               K - K 6         2. K - Kt 2
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 2. ........               K - B 5         3. K - B 2                K - Kt 5

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 2. ........               K - B 5         3. K - B 2                K - Kt 5

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 16/95
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 2. ........               K - B 5         3. K - B 2                K - Kt 5

blocks.text: 4. K - Kt 2               K - R 5         5. K - Kt 1               K - R 6
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 4. K - Kt 2               K - R 5         5. K - Kt 1               K - R 6

blocks.text: The first part has been completed.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 4. K - Kt 2               K - R 5         5. K - Kt 1               K - R 6

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 4. K - Kt 2               K - R 5         5. K - Kt 1               K - R 6

blocks.text: The second part will be short and will consist in advancing the R P up the K.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 4. K - Kt 2               K - R 5         5. K - Kt 1               K - R 6

blocks.text: 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5

blocks.text: This ends the second part.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5

blocks.text: [Illustration] {39}
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5

blocks.text: The third part will consist in timing the advance of the Kt P so as to play P - Kt 6 when the White King is at R 1. It now becomes evident how necessary it is to be able to move the Kt P either one or two squares according to the position of the White King, as indicated previously.[2] In this case, as it is White's move, the Pawn will be advanced two squares since the White King will be in the corner, but if it were now Black's move the Kt P should only be advanced one square since the White King is at Kt 1.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5

blocks.text: 8. K - R 1                P - Kt 4         9. K - Kt 1               P - Kt 5        10. K - R 1                P - Kt 6        11. P x P
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5

blocks.text: If K - Kt 1, P - Kt 7.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5

blocks.text: and wins.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5

blocks.text: It is in this analytical way that the student should try to learn. He will thus train his mind to follow a logical sequence in reasoning out any position. This example is excellent training, since it is easy to divide it into three stages and to explain the main point of each part.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5

blocks.text: The next subject we shall study is the simple {40} opposition, but before we devote our time to it I wish to call attention to two things.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 6. K - R 1                P - R 4         7. K - Kt 1               P - R 5

blocks.text: 11. OBTAINING A PASSED PAWN
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 11. OBTAINING A PASSED PAWN

blocks.text: When three or more Pawns are opposed to each other in some such position as the one in Example 24, there is always a chance for one side or the other of obtaining a passed Pawn.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 11. OBTAINING A PASSED PAWN

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 11. OBTAINING A PASSED PAWN

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 24.--In the above position the way of obtaining a passed Pawn is to advance the centre Pawn.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 11. OBTAINING A PASSED PAWN

blocks.text: 1. P - Kt 6               R P x P   If B P x P; P - R 6,         2. P - B 6                P x B P         3. P - R 6
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 11. OBTAINING A PASSED PAWN

blocks.text: and as in this case the White Pawn is nearer to Queen than any of the Black Pawns, White will {41} win. Now if it had been Black's move Black could play
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 11. OBTAINING A PASSED PAWN

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 11. OBTAINING A PASSED PAWN

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 17/95
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 11. OBTAINING A PASSED PAWN

blocks.text: 1. ........               P - Kt 3         2. B P x P                B P x P
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. ........               P - Kt 3         2. B P x P                B P x P

blocks.text: It would not be advisable to try to obtain a passed Pawn because the White Pawns would be nearer to Queen than the single Black Pawn.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. ........               P - Kt 3         2. B P x P                B P x P

blocks.text: 3. P x P                  P x P
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P x P

blocks.text: and the game properly played would be a draw. The student should work this out for himself.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P x P
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P x P

blocks.text: 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN

blocks.text: When two Pawns are free, or will be free, to advance to Queen, you can find out, by counting, which Pawn will be the first to succeed.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 25.--In this position whoever moves first wins.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN

blocks.text: [Illustration] {42}
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN

blocks.text: The first thing is to find out, by counting, whether the opposing King can be in time to stop the passed Pawn from Queening. When, as in this case, it cannot be done, the point is to count which Pawn comes in first. In this case the time is the same, but the Pawn that reaches the eighth square first and becomes a Queen is in a position to capture the adversary's Queen when he makes one. Thus:
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN

blocks.text: 1. P - R 4                P - K R 4         2. P - R 5                P - R 5         3. P - Kt 6               P x P
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN

blocks.text: Now comes a little calculation. White can capture the Pawn, but if he does so, he will not, when Queening, command the square where Black will also Queen his Pawn. Therefore, instead of taking, he plays:
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN

blocks.text: 4. P - R 6                P - R 6         5. P - R 7                P - R 7         6. P - R 8 (Q), and wins.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN

blocks.text: The student would do well to acquaint himself with various simple endings of this sort, so as to acquire the habit of counting, and thus be able to know with ease when he can or cannot get there first. Once again I must call attention to the fact that a book cannot by itself teach how to play. It can only serve as a guide, and the rest must be learned by experience, and if a teacher can be had at the same time, so much the faster will the student be able to learn. {43}
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 12. HOW TO FIND OUT WHICH PAWN WILL BE FIRST TO QUEEN

blocks.text: 13. THE OPPOSITION
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 13. THE OPPOSITION

blocks.text: When Kings have to be moved, and one player can, by force, bring his King into a position similar to the one shown in the following diagram, so that his adversary is forced to move and make way for him, the player obtaining that advantage is said to have _the opposition_.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 13. THE OPPOSITION

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 13. THE OPPOSITION

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 26.--Suppose in the above position White plays
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 13. THE OPPOSITION
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: Now Black has the option of either opposing the passage of the White King by playing K - Q 3 or, if he prefers, he can _pass_ with his own King by replying K - B 4. Notice that the Kings are directly opposed to each other, and the number of intervening squares between them is odd--one in this case.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 18/95
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: The opposition can take the form shown above, {44} which can be called actual or close frontal opposition; or this form:
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: which can be called actual or close diagonal opposition, or, again, this form:
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: which can be called actual or close lateral opposition.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: In practice they are all one and the same. The Kings are always on squares of the same colour, there is only one intervening square between the Kings, and the player who has moved last "_has the opposition_." {45}
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: Now, if the student will take the trouble of moving each King backwards as in a game in the same frontal, diagonal or lateral line respectively shown in the diagrams, we shall have what may be called _distant_ frontal, diagonal and lateral opposition respectively.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: The matter of the opposition is highly important, and takes at times somewhat complicated forms, all of which can be solved mathematically; but, for the present, the student should only consider the most simple forms. (An examination of some of the examples of King and Pawns endings already given will show several cases of close opposition.)
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: In all simple forms of opposition,
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: _when the Kings are on the same line and the number of intervening squares between them is even, the player who has the move has the opposition_.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 27.--The above position shows to advantage the enormous value of the opposition. The {46} position is very simple. Very little is left on the board, and the position, to a beginner, probably looks absolutely even. It is not the case, however. _Whoever has the move wins._ Notice that the Kings are directly in front of one another, and that the number of intervening squares is _even_.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: Now as to the procedure to win such a position. The proper way to begin is to move straight up. Thus:
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: 1. K - K 2                K - K 2         2. K - K 3                K - K 3         3. K - K 4                K - B 3
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: Now White can exercise the option of either playing K - Q 5 and thus passing with his King, or of playing K - B 4 and prevent the Black King from passing, thereby keeping the opposition. Mere counting will show that the former course will only lead to a draw, therefore White takes the latter course and plays:
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - Q 4

blocks.text: 4. K - B 4                K - Kt 3
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 4. K - B 4                K - Kt 3

blocks.text: If 4...K - K 3; 5 K - Kt 5 will win.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 4. K - B 4                K - Kt 3

blocks.text: 5. K - K 5                K - Kt 2
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 5. K - K 5                K - Kt 2

blocks.text: Now by counting it will be seen that White wins by capturing Black's Knight Pawn.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 5. K - K 5                K - Kt 2

blocks.text: The process has been comparatively simple in the variation given above, but Black has other lines of {47} defence more difficult to overcome. Let us begin anew.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 5. K - K 5                K - Kt 2

blocks.text: 1. K - K 2                K - Q 1
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 1

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 1

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 19/95
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 1

blocks.text: Now if 2 K - Q 3, K - Q 2, or if 2 K - K 3, K - K 2, and Black obtains the opposition in both cases. (When the Kings are directly in front of one another, and the number of intervening squares between the Kings is _odd_, the player who has moved last has the opposition.)
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 1

blocks.text: Now in order to win, the White King must advance. There is only one other square where he can go, B 3, and that is the right place. Therefore it is seen that in such cases when the opponent makes a so-called waiting move, you must advance, leaving a rank or file free between the Kings. Therefore we have--
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 1

blocks.text: 2. K - B 3                K - K 2
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 2. K - B 3                K - K 2

blocks.text: Now, it would be bad to advance, because then Black, by bringing up his King in front of your King, would obtain the opposition. It is White's turn to play a similar move to Black's first move, viz.:
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 2. K - B 3                K - K 2
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. K - K 3

blocks.text: which brings the position back to the first variation shown. The student would do well to familiarise himself with the handling of the King in all examples of opposition. It often means the winning or losing of a game.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. K - K 3

blocks.text: {48} EXAMPLE 28.--The following position is an excellent proof of the value of the opposition as a means of defence.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. K - K 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. K - K 3

blocks.text: White is a Pawn behind and apparently lost, yet he can manage to draw as follows:
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. K - K 3
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - R 1 !

blocks.text: The position of the Pawns does not permit White to draw by means of the actual or close opposition, hence he takes the distant opposition: in effect if 1 K - B 1 (actual or close opposition), K - Q 7; 2 K - B 2, K - Q 6 and White cannot continue to keep the lateral opposition essential to his safety, because of his own Pawn at B 3. On the other hand, after the text move, if
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - R 1 !
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - R 1 !

blocks.text: attacking the Pawn and forcing Black to play 6... K - K 6 when he can go back to Kt 3 as already shown, and always keep the opposition.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - R 1 !

blocks.text: Going back to the original position, if
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - R 1 !

blocks.text: 1. K - R 1                P - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - R 1                P - Kt 5

blocks.text: White does not play P x P, because P - K 5 will win, but plays:
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. K - R 1                P - Kt 5

blocks.text: 2. K - Kt 2               K - Q 7
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 2. K - Kt 2               K - Q 7

blocks.text: If 2...P x P ch; 3 K x P, followed by K - K 4, will draw.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 2. K - Kt 2               K - Q 7

blocks.text: 3. P x P                  P - K 5
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P - K 5

blocks.text: and mere counting will show that both sides Queen, drawing the game.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P - K 5

blocks.text: If the student will now take the trouble to go back to the examples of King and Pawns which I have given in this book,[3] he will realise that in all of them the matter of the opposition is of paramount importance; as, in
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P - K 5

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P - K 5

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 20/95
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P - K 5

blocks.text: fact, it is in nearly all endings of King and Pawns, except in such cases where the Pawn-position in itself ensures the win.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P - K 5
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P - K 5
FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 3. P x P                  P - K 5

blocks.text: 14. THE RELATIVE VALUE OF KNIGHT AND BISHOP
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 14. THE RELATIVE VALUE OF KNIGHT AND BISHOP

blocks.text: Before turning our attention to this matter it is well to state now that _two Knights alone cannot mate_, but, under certain conditions of course, they can do so if the opponent has one or more Pawns.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 14. THE RELATIVE VALUE OF KNIGHT AND BISHOP

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 14. THE RELATIVE VALUE OF KNIGHT AND BISHOP

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 29.--In the above position White cannot win, although the Black King is cornered, but in the following position, in which Black has a Pawn,
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 14. THE RELATIVE VALUE OF KNIGHT AND BISHOP

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 14. THE RELATIVE VALUE OF KNIGHT AND BISHOP

blocks.text: White wins with or without the move. Thus:
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 14. THE RELATIVE VALUE OF KNIGHT AND BISHOP

blocks.text: 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: {51} White cannot take the Pawn because the game will be drawn, as explained before.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: 2. Kt - K 5               P - R 6         3. Kt - B 6               P - R 7         4. Kt - Kt 5              P - R 8 (Q)         5. Kt - B 7 mate
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: The reason for this peculiarity in chess is evident.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: _White with the two Knights can only stalemate the King, unless Black has a Pawn which can be moved._
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 30.--Although he is a Bishop and a Pawn ahead the following position cannot be won by White.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: It is the greatest weakness of the Bishop, that when the Rook's Pawn Queens on a square of opposite colour and the opposing King is in front of the Pawn, the Bishop is absolutely worthless. All that Black has to do is to keep moving his King close to the corner square. {52}
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 31.--In the above position White with or without the move can win. Take the most difficult variation.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: 1. ........               K - R 7         2. Kt - Kt 4 ch           K - R 8         3. K - B 1                P - Kt 4         4. K - B 2                P - R 7         5. Kt - K 3               P - Kt 5         6. Kt - B 1               P - Kt 6 ch         7. Kt x P mate
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: Now that we have seen these exceptional cases, we can analyse the different merits and the relative value of the Knight and the Bishop.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: It is generally thought by amateurs that the Knight is the more valuable piece of the two, the chief reason being that, unlike the Bishop, the Knight can command both Black and White squares. However, the fact is generally overlooked that the Knight, at any one time, {53} has the choice of one colour only. It takes much longer to bring a Knight from one wing to the other. Also, as shown in the following Example, a Bishop can stalemate
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 21/95
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: a Knight; a compliment which the Knight is unable to return.
blocks.section_path: FURTHER PRINCIPLES IN END-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt - Kt 6              P - R 5

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 32.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: The weaker the player the more terrible the Knight is to him, but as a player increases in strength the value of the Bishop becomes more evident to him, and of course there is, or should be, a corresponding decrease in his estimation of the value of the Knight as compared to the Bishop. In this respect, as in many others, the masters of to-day are far ahead of the masters of former generations. While not so long ago some of the very best amongst them, like Pillsbury and Tchigorin, preferred Knights to Bishops, there is hardly a master of to-day who would not completely agree with the statements made above. {54}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 33.--This is about the only case when the Knight is more valuable than the Bishop.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: It is what is called a "_block position_," and all the Pawns are on one side of the board. (If there were Pawns on both sides of the board there would be no advantage in having a Knight.) In such a position Black has excellent chances of winning. Of course, there is an extra source of weakness for White in having his Pawns on the same colour-squares as his Bishop. This is a mistake often made by players. The proper way, generally, in an ending, is to have your Pawns on squares of opposite colour to that of your own Bishop. When you have your Pawns on squares of the same colour the action of your own Bishop is limited by them, and consequently the value of the Bishop is diminished, since the value of a piece can often be measured by the number of squares it commands. While on this subject, I shall also call attention to the {55} fact that it is generally preferable to keep your Pawns on squares of the same colour as that of the opposing Bishop, particularly if they are passed Pawns supported by the King. The principles might be stated thus:
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: _When the opponent has a Bishop, keep your Pawns on squares of the same colour as your opponent's Bishop._
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: _Whenever you have a Bishop, whether the opponent has also one or not, keep your Pawns on squares of the opposite colour to that of your own Bishop._
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: Naturally, these principles have sometimes to be modified to suit the exigencies of the position.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 34.--In the following position the Pawns are on one side of the board, and there is no advantage in having either a Knight or a Bishop. The game should surely end in a draw.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: [Illustration] {56}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 35.--Now let us add three Pawns on each side to the above position, so that there are Pawns on both sides of the board.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: It is now preferable to have the Bishop, though the position, if properly played out, should end in a draw. The advantage of having the Bishop lies as much in its ability to command, at long range, both sides of the board from a central position as in its ability to move quickly from one side of the board to the other.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: [Illustration] {57}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 36.--In the above position it is unquestionably an advantage to have the Bishop, because, although each player has the same number of Pawns, they are not balanced on each side of the board. Thus, on the King's side, White has three to two, while on the Queen's side it is Black that
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 22/95
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: has three to two. Still, with proper play, the game should end in a draw, though White has somewhat better chances.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 37.--Here is a position in which to have the Bishop is a decided advantage, since not only are there Pawns on both sides of the board, but there is a passed Pawn (K R P for White, Q R P for Black). Black should have extreme difficulty in drawing this position, if he can do it at all. {58}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 38.--Again Black would have great difficulty in drawing this position.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: The student should carefully consider these positions. I hope that the many examples will help him to understand, in their true value, the relative merits of the Knight and Bishop. As to the general method of procedure, a teacher, or practical experience, will be best. I might say generally, however, that the proper course in these endings, as in all similar endings, is: Advance of the King to the centre of the board or towards the passed Pawns, or Pawns that are susceptible of being attacked, and rapid advance of the passed Pawn or Pawns as far as is consistent with their safety.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: To give a fixed line of play would be folly. Each ending is different, and requires different handling, according to what the adversary proposes to do. Calculation by visualising the future positions is what will count. {59}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32.
EXAMPLE 32.

blocks.text: 15. HOW TO MATE WITH A KNIGHT AND A BISHOP
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 15. HOW TO MATE WITH A KNIGHT AND A BISHOP

blocks.text: Now, before going back again to the middle-game and the openings, let us see how to mate with Knight and Bishop, and, then, how to win with a Queen against a Rook.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 15. HOW TO MATE WITH A KNIGHT AND A BISHOP

blocks.text: With a Knight and a Bishop _the mate can only be given in the corners of the same colour as the Bishop_.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 15. HOW TO MATE WITH A KNIGHT AND A BISHOP

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 15. HOW TO MATE WITH A KNIGHT AND A BISHOP

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 39.--In this example we must mate either at Q R 1 or K R 8. The ending can be divided into two parts. Part one consists in driving the Black King to the last line. We might begin, as is generally done in all such cases, by advancing the King to the centre of the board:
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 15. HOW TO MATE WITH A KNIGHT AND A BISHOP

blocks.text: 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: Black, in order to make it more difficult, goes towards the white-squared corner:
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: 2. K - Q 3                K - B 3         3. B - B 4                K - Q 4   {60}         4. Kt - K 2               K - B 4         5. Kt - B 3               K - Kt 5         6. K - Q 4                K - R 4         7. K - B 5                K - R 3         8. K - B 6                K - R 2         9. Kt - Q 5               K - R 1
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: The first part is now over; the Black King is in the white-squared corner.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: The second and last part will consist in driving the Black King now from
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 23/95
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: Q R 8 to Q R 1 or K R 8 in order to mate him. Q R 1 will be the quickest in this position.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: 10. Kt - Kt 6 ch           K - R 2        11. B - B 7                K - R 3        12. B - Kt 8               K - R 4        13. Kt - Q 5               K - R 5
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: Black tries to make for K R 1 with his King. White has two ways to prevent that, one by 14 B - K 5, {61} K - Kt 6; 15 Kt - K 3, and the other which I give as the text, and which I consider better for the student to learn, because it is more methodical and more in accord with the spirit of all these endings, _by using the King as much as possible_.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: 14. K - B 5 !              K - Kt 6        15. Kt - Kt 4              K - B 6        16. B - B 4                K - Kt 6        17. B - K 5                K - R 5        18. K - B 4                K - R 4        19. B - B 7 ch             K - R 5        20. Kt - Q 3               K - R 6        21. B - Kt 6               K - R 5        22. Kt - Kt 2 ch           K - R 6        23. K - B 3                K - R 7        24. K - B 2                K - R 6        25. B - B 5 ch             K - R 7        26. Kt - Q 3               K - R 8        27. B - Kt 4               K - R 7        28. Kt - B 1 ch            K - R 8        29. B - B 3 mate
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: It will be seen that the ending is rather laborious. There are two outstanding features: the close following by the King, and the controlling of the squares of opposite colour to the Bishop by the combined action of the Knight and King. The student would do well to exercise himself methodically in this ending, as it gives a very good idea of the actual power of the pieces, and it requires foresight in order to accomplish the {62} mate within the fifty moves which are granted by the rules.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2
EXAMPLE 32. > 1. K - K 2                K - Q 2

blocks.text: 16. QUEEN AGAINST ROOK
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 16. QUEEN AGAINST ROOK

blocks.text: This is one of the most difficult endings without Pawns. The resources of the defence are many, and when used skilfully only a very good player will prevail within the limit of fifty moves allowed by the rules. (The rule is that at any moment you may demand that your opponent mate you within fifty moves. However, every time a piece is exchanged or a Pawn advanced the counting must begin afresh.)
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 16. QUEEN AGAINST ROOK

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 16. QUEEN AGAINST ROOK

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 40.--This is one of the standard positions which Black can often bring about. Now, it is White's move. If it were Black's move it would be simple, as he would have to move his Rook away from the King (find out why), and then the Rook would be {63} comparatively easy to win. We deduce from the above that the main object is to force the Black Rook away from the defending King, and that, in order to compel Black to do so, we must bring about the position in the diagram with _Black_ to move. Once we know what is required, the way to proceed becomes easier to find. Thus:
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 16. QUEEN AGAINST ROOK

blocks.text: 1. Q - K 5 ch

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 41.--The procedure here is very similar. The things to bear in mind are that the Rook must be prevented from interposing at Kt 1 because of an immediate mate, and in the same way the King must be prevented from going either to R 3 or B 1.

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 42.--We shall now examine a more difficult position.

blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. Q - K 5 ch

blocks.text: Many players would be deceived by this position. The most likely looking move is not the best. Thus suppose we begin
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. Q - K 5 ch

blocks.text: 1. Q - K 5 ch             K - B 1         2. K - Kt 6               R - Q 2
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. Q - K 5 ch             K - B 1         2. K - Kt 6               R - Q 2

blocks.text: The only defence, but, unfortunately, a very effective one, which makes it very difficult for White, since he cannot play 3 Q - K 6 because of 3...R - Kt 2 ch; 4 K - B 6, R - Kt 3 ch draws. Nor can he win quickly by 3 Q - Q B 5 ch because 3...K - K 1, 4 K - B 6, R - Q 3 ch ! driving back the White King.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. Q - K 5 ch             K - B 1         2. K - Kt 6               R - Q 2

blocks.text: Now that we have seen the difficulties of the situation let us go back. The best move is

blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 1. Q - Kt 5 ch !          K - R 1

blocks.text: If K - R 2; 2 Q - Kt 6 ch, K - R 1; 3 K - R 6 !

blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 2. Q - K 5 ch !           K - R 2 best         3. K - Kt 5               R - R 2 ! best

blocks.text: If 3...R - Kt 2 ch; 4 K - B 6 leads to a position similar to those in Examples 40 and 41.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 2. Q - K 5 ch !           K - R 2 best         3. K - Kt 5               R - R 2 ! best

blocks.text: 4. Q - K 4 ch             K - Kt 1         5. Q - B 4 ch             K - R 2         6. K - B 6                R - K Kt 2         7. Q - R 4 ch             K - Kt 1         8. Q - R 5
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 2. Q - K 5 ch !           K - R 2 best         3. K - Kt 5               R - R 2 ! best

blocks.text: {66} and we have the position of Example 40 with Black to move.

blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 32. > 2. Q - K 5 ch !           K - R 2 best         3. K - Kt 5               R - R 2 ! best

blocks.text: Note, in these examples, that the checks at long range along the diagonals have often been the key to all the winning manoeuvres. Also that the Queen and {67} King are often kept on different lines. The student should carefully go over these positions and consider all the possibilities not given in the text.

blocks.text: CHAPTER III
blocks.section_path: CHAPTER III

blocks.text: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY

blocks.text: I shall now give a few winning positions taken from my own games. I have selected those that I believe can be considered as _types_, i.e. positions that may easily occur again in a somewhat similar form. A knowledge of such positions is of great help; in fact, one cannot know too many. It often may help the player to find, with little effort, the right move, which he might not be able to find at all without such knowledge.
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY

blocks.text: 17. ATTACKING WITHOUT THE AID OF KNIGHTS
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 17. ATTACKING WITHOUT THE AID OF KNIGHTS

blocks.text: [Illustration] {69}
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 17. ATTACKING WITHOUT THE AID OF KNIGHTS

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 43.--It is Black's move, and as he is a Kt and P behind he must win quickly, if at all. He plays:
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 17. ATTACKING WITHOUT THE AID OF KNIGHTS
PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. ........               Q R - Kt 1 !         2. R - B 2

blocks.text: If, Q x Q, R x P ch; K - R 1, B - Q 4 and mate follows in a few moves.
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. ........               Q R - Kt 1 !         2. R - B 2

blocks.text: 2. ........               R x P ch         3. K - B 1                B - B 5 ch         4. Kt x B                 R - Kt 8 mate

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 44.--Black's last move was P - K 6, played with the object of stopping what he thought was White's threat, viz.: R - Q R 5, to which he would have answered Q - B 5 ch and drawn the game by perpetual check. White, however, has a more forceful move, and he mates in three moves as follows: {70}

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 45.--White has a beautiful position, but still he had better gain some material, if he can, before Black consolidates his defensive position. He therefore plays:
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. ........               Q R - Kt 1 !         2. R - B 2

blocks.text: 1. R x Kt !               P x R         2. B x P ch               K - K 2
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. R x Kt !               P x R         2. B x P ch               K - K 2

blocks.text: If Kt x B; R x Kt and Black would be helpless.
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. R x Kt !               P x R         2. B x P ch               K - K 2

blocks.text: 3. Q - R 7 ch             K - K 1         4. Q x Kt ch              K - Q 2         5. Q - R 7 ch             Q - K 2         6. B - B 8                Q x Q         7. R x Q ch               K - K 1         8. R x R                  Resigns
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. R x Kt !               P x R         2. B x P ch               K - K 2

blocks.text: In these few examples the attacking has been done by Rooks and Bishops in combination with the Queen. {71} There have been no Knights to take part in the attack. We shall now give some examples in which the Knights play a prominent part as an attacking force.

blocks.text: 18. ATTACKING WITH KNIGHTS AS A PROMINENT FORCE
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 18. ATTACKING WITH KNIGHTS AS A PROMINENT FORCE

blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 18. ATTACKING WITH KNIGHTS AS A PROMINENT FORCE

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 46.--White is two Pawns behind. He must therefore press on his attack. The game continues:
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 18. ATTACKING WITH KNIGHTS AS A PROMINENT FORCE

blocks.text: 1. Kt (B 5) x Kt P        Kt - B 4
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt (B 5) x Kt P        Kt - B 4

blocks.text: Evidently an error which made the winning easier for White, as he simply took the Rook with the Knight and kept up the attack. Black should have played: 1 ... Kt x Kt. Then would have followed: 2 Kt - B 6 ch, K - Kt 3; 3 Kt x B, P - B 3 (best); 4 P - K 5, K - B 2; 5 Kt x P, R - K 2; 6 Kt - K 4, and Black should lose.[4]
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt (B 5) x Kt P        Kt - B 4
PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt (B 5) x Kt P        Kt - B 4

blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt (B 5) x Kt P        Kt - B 4

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 47.--The student should carefully examine the position, as the sacrifice of the Bishop in similar situations is typical, and the chance for it is of frequent occurrence in actual play. The game continues:
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. Kt (B 5) x Kt P        Kt - B 4

blocks.text: 1. B x P ch               K x B         2. Kt - Kt 5 ch           K - Kt 3
blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 1. B x P ch               K x B         2. Kt - Kt 5 ch           K - Kt 3

blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 3. Q - Kt 4               P - B 4         4. Q - Kt 3               K - R 3

blocks.section_path: PLANNING A WIN IN MIDDLE-GAME PLAY > 3. Q - Kt 4               P - B 4         4. Q - Kt 3               K - R 3
