blocks.text: 1. P x P, P x P; 2. Q - K B 3, Q - Q 2
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 1. P x P, P x P; 2. Q - K B 3, Q - Q 2

blocks.text: White threatened to win a Pawn by Q x P, and Black could not play 2...R - K B 1, because 3 R x B P would also win a Pawn at least.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 1. P x P, P x P; 2. Q - K B 3, Q - Q 2

blocks.text: 3. R (B 5) - B 2,         R - Kt 3;         4. R - Kt 2,              K - R 1;         5. R (B 1) - K Kt 1,      R (B 1) - K Kt 1;         6. Q - R 5,               R x R;         7. R x R,                 R x R;         8. K x R,                 Q - Kt 2 ch;         9. K - R 2,               Q - Kt 3;        10. Q x Q,                 P x Q;        11. P - Kt 4, and White wins.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 1. P x P, P x P; 2. Q - K B 3, Q - Q 2

blocks.text: Now suppose that in the position in the preceding diagram it were Black's move, and he played R - K B 1. White would then simply defend his K B P by some move like Q - K B 3, threatening R x Q B P, and then he would bring his King up to Kt 3, and when the time came, break through, as in the previous case. White might even be able to obtain the following position:
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 1. P x P, P x P; 2. Q - K B 3, Q - Q 2

blocks.text: [Illustration] {150}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 1. P x P, P x P; 2. Q - K B 3, Q - Q 2

blocks.text: Black would now be forced to play R - B 1, and White could then play Q - B 2, and follow it up with K B 3, and thus force Black to play P x P, which would give White a greater advantage.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 1. P x P, P x P; 2. Q - K B 3, Q - Q 2

blocks.text: A careful examination of all these positions will reveal that, besides the advantage of freedom of manoeuvre on White's part, the power of the Pawn at K 5 is enormous, and that it is the commanding position of this Pawn, and the fact that it is free to advance, once all the pieces are exchanged, that constitute the pivot of all White's manoeuvres.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 1. P x P, P x P; 2. Q - K B 3, Q - Q 2

blocks.text: I have purposely given positions without the moves which lead to them so that the student may become accustomed to build up in his own mind possible positions that may arise (out of any given situation). Thus he will learn to make strategical plans and be on his way to the master class. The student can derive enormous benefit by further practice of this kind.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 1. P x P, P x P; 2. Q - K B 3, Q - Q 2

blocks.text: 33. THE INFLUENCE OF A "HOLE"
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 33. THE INFLUENCE OF A "HOLE"

blocks.text: The influence of a so-called "hole" in a game has already been illustrated in my game against Blanco (page 81), where has been shown the influence exercised by the different pieces posted in the hole created at White's K 5. {151}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 33. THE INFLUENCE OF A "HOLE"

blocks.text: EXAMPLE 67.--In order to further illustrate this point, I now give a game played in the Havana International Masters Tournament of 1913. (Queen's Gambit Declined.) White: D. Janowski. Black: A. Kupchick.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 33. THE INFLUENCE OF A "HOLE"

blocks.text: 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4         2. P - Q B 4              P - K 3         3. Kt - Q B 3             Kt - K B 3         4. B - Kt 5               B - K 2         5. P - K 3                Q Kt - Q 2         6. B - Q 3                P x P         7. B x P                  Kt - Kt 3
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 33. THE INFLUENCE OF A "HOLE"

blocks.text: Of course the idea is to post a Knight at Q 4, but as it is the other Knight which will be posted there this manoeuvre does not seem logical. The Knight at Kt 3 does nothing except to prevent the development of his own Q B. The normal course O - O, followed by P - Q B 4, is more reasonable. For a beautiful illustration of how to play White in that variation, see the Janowski-Rubinstein game of the St. Petersburg Tournament of 1914.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 33. THE INFLUENCE OF A "HOLE"
EXAMPLE 66. > 8. B - Q 3

blocks.text: B - Kt 3 has some points in its favour in this position, the most important
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 8. B - Q 3

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 8. B - Q 3

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 55/95
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 8. B - Q 3

blocks.text: being the possibility of advancing the King's Pawn immediately after 8. ... K Kt - Q 4; 9 B x B, Q x B.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 8. B - Q 3

blocks.text: 8. ........               K Kt - Q 4         9. B x B                  Q x B        10. Kt - B 3
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 8. ........               K Kt - Q 4         9. B x B                  Q x B        10. Kt - B 3

blocks.text: {152} Had White's Bishop been at Q Kt 3 he could now play P - K 4 as indicated in the previous note, a move which he cannot make in the present position, because of Kt - K B 5 threatening, not only the K Kt P, but also Kt x B ch. As White's King's Bishop should never be exchanged in this opening without a very good reason White therefore cannot play P - K 4.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 8. ........               K Kt - Q 4         9. B x B                  Q x B        10. Kt - B 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
White is perfectly developed, and now threatens to win a Pawn as follows: Kt x Kt, Kt x Kt; P - K 4, followed by R x P.

The fact that Black is practically forced to make this move in order to avoid the loss of a Pawn is sufficient reason in itself to condemn the whole system of development on Black's part. In effect, he plays B - Q 2 and now he has to shut off the action of his {153} own Bishop, which thereby becomes little more than a Pawn for a while. In fact, it is hard to see how this Bishop will ever be able to attack anything. Besides, it can be easily seen that White will soon post his two Knights at K 5 and Q B 5 respectively, and that Black will not be able to dislodge them without seriously weakening his game, if he can do it at all. From all these reasons it can be gathered that it would probably have been better for Black to play Kt x Kt and thus get rid of one of the two White Knights before assuming such a defensive position. In such cases, the less the number of pieces on the board, the better chances there are to escape.
13. Kt - K 4               P - K B 4
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 13. Kt - K 4               P - K B 4

blocks.text: This practically amounts to committing suicide, since it creates a hole at K 5 for White's Knight, from where it will be practically impossible to dislodge him. If Black intended to make such a move he should have done it before, when at least there would have been an object in preventing the White Knight from reaching B 5.
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 13. Kt - K 4               P - K B 4

blocks.text: 14. Kt - B 5               B - K 1        15. Kt - K 5
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 14. Kt - B 5               B - K 1        15. Kt - K 5

blocks.text: The position of White's Knights, especially the one at K 5, might be said to be ideal, and a single glance shows how they dominate the position. The question henceforth will be how is White going to derive the full benefit from such an advantageous situation, This we shall soon see. {154}
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 14. Kt - B 5               B - K 1        15. Kt - K 5

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: EXAMPLE 66. > 14. Kt - B 5               B - K 1        15. Kt - K 5

blocks.text: There is no object in this move, unless it is to be followed by Kt - Q 2. As that is not the case, he might have gone with the Rook to B 1, as he does later.
White threatened to win the exchange by playing either Kt - B 7 or Kt - Kt 4.

blocks.text: PART II
blocks.section_path: PART II

blocks.text: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED
blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: (Match, 1909)
blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: White: F. J. Marshall. Black: J. R. Capablanca.
blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4         2. P - Q B 4              P - K 3         3. Kt - Q B 3             Kt - K B 3         4. B - Kt 5               B - K 2         5. P - K 3                Kt - K 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: I had played this defence twice before in the match with good results, and although I lost this game I still played it until the very last game, when I changed my tactics. The reason was my total lack of knowledge of the different variations in this opening, coupled with the fact that I knew that Dr. E. Lasker had been successful with it against Marshall himself in 1907. I thought that since Dr. Lasker had played it so often, it should be good. The object is to exchange a couple of pieces and at the same time to bring about a position full of possibilities and with promising chances of success once the end-game stage is reached. On general principles it should be wrong, because the {160} same Knight is moved three times in the opening, although it involves the exchange of two pieces. In reality the difficulty in this variation, as well as in nearly all the variations of the Queen's gambit, lies in the slow development of Black's Queen Bishop. However, whether this variation can or cannot be safely played is a question still to be decided, and it is outside the scope of this book. I may add that at present my preference is for a different system of development, but it is not unlikely that I should some time come back to this variation.
blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: 6. B x B                  Q x B         7. B - Q 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 6. B x B                  Q x B         7. B - Q 3

blocks.text: P x P is preferable for reasons that we shall soon see.
blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 6. B x B                  Q x B         7. B - Q 3

blocks.text: 7. ........               Kt x Kt         8. P x Kt                 Kt - Q 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 7. ........               Kt x Kt         8. P x Kt                 Kt - Q 2

blocks.text: Now P x P would be a better way to develop the game. The idea is that after 8...P x P; 9 B x B P, P - Q Kt 3, followed by B - Kt 2, would give Black's Bishop a powerful range. For this variation see the eleventh game of the match.
blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 7. ........               Kt x Kt         8. P x Kt                 Kt - Q 2

blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 9. Kt - B 3               O - O

blocks.text: No longer would 9...P x P; 10 B x P, P - Q Kt 3 be good, because 11 B - Kt 5 would prevent B - Kt 2 on account of Kt - K 5. {161}
blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 9. Kt - B 3               O - O

blocks.section_path: GAME 1. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 9. Kt - B 3               O - O

blocks.text: Played with the intention of obtaining the majority of Pawns on the Queen's side. Yet it is doubtful whether this move is good, since it leaves Black's Queen's-side Pawns disrupted in a way. The safer course would have been to play P - B 3.

Then after 14 Q x P, Q x Q would follow, and I believe that Black would regain the Pawn. If, instead, White played 14 P x P then B - Kt 5 would give Black an excellent game.

It never even passed through my mind that this was threatened. Black's best move would have been 16...K R - Kt 1. If that loses, then any other move would lose as well.

blocks.text: GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED
blocks.section_path: GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: (San Sebastian, 1911)
blocks.section_path: GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: White: A. K. Rubinstein. Black: J. R. Capablanca.
blocks.section_path: GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4         2. Kt - K B 3             P - Q B 4         3. P - B 4                P - K 3         4. P x Q P                K P x P         5. Kt - B 3               Kt -Q B 3         6. P - K Kt 3             B - K 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: Kt - B 3 is the normal move in this variation. White's development was first introduced by Schlechter and elaborated later on by Rubinstein. It aims at the isolation of Black's Q P, against which the White pieces are gradually concentrated. In making the text move I was trying to avoid the beaten track. Being a developing move there should be no objection to it in the way of general principles, except that the Knights ought to come out before the Bishops.
blocks.section_path: GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: 7. B - Kt 2               B - K 2         8. O - O                  R - B 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 7. B - Kt 2               B - K 2         8. O - O                  R - B 1

blocks.text: In pursuance of the idea of changing the normal {164} course of this variation, but with very poor success. The move in theory ought to be unsound, since Black's K Kt is yet undeveloped. I had not yet learned of the attack founded on Kt - Kt 5 and the exchange of the B at K 3. Either Kt - B 3 or P - K R 3; to prevent either B or Kt - K Kt 5, was right.

blocks.text: This is a mistake. The right move was R - Q 1 in order to get the Rook away from the line of the Bishop at R 3 and at the same time to support the Q P. Incidentally it shows that White failed to take proper advantage of Black's weak opening moves. Against the text move White makes a very fine combination {165} which I had seen, but which I thought could be defeated.
blocks.section_path: GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 9. P X P                  B x P

blocks.text: 14. B x Kt                 Q x B
blocks.section_path: GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 14. B x Kt                 Q x B

blocks.text: I considered P x B, which it seemed would give me a playable game, but I thought White's combination unsound and therefore let him play it, to my lasting regret.

blocks.text: _This_ is the move which I had not considered. I thought that Rubinstein would have to play B - Kt 2, when I had in mind the following winning combination: 16 B - Kt 2, Kt - K 4 ! 17 Kt - B 4 (if R - B 1, Q x R !! Q x Q, B x P ch wins), Kt - Kt 5; 18 P - K R 3 (if Kt - R 3, B x P ch wins the exchange), Kt x P; 19 R x Kt, B x R ch; 20 K x B, P - K Kt 4, and Black should win. It is curious that this combination has been overlooked. It has been taken for granted that I did not see the 17th move Q - B 1.
blocks.section_path: GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 16. K - Kt 2 !
GAME 2. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 16. ........               Q R - Q 1

blocks.text: After White's last move there was nothing for me to do but submit to the inevitable.

blocks.text: This gives Black a chance. He should have played K R - K 1. If then Kt - B 7; R x R ch, R x R; R - Q B 1, R - K 7; K - B 1, Kt - Q 5 (if R - Q 7; B - K 6 ch, K - B 1; B x P would win); R - B 8 ch, K - B 2; R - B 7 ch, R - K 2; R - B 5 wins. {167}

blocks.text: A bad move, which gives away any legitimate chance Black had to draw. It loses a very important move. In fact, as the course of the game will show, it loses several moves. The proper way was to play K - Q 3. If then R - Q Kt 5, R x R; B x R, Kt - Q 5; followed by P - Q Kt 4; and White would have an exceedingly difficult game to draw on account of the dominating

blocks.text: With these last three moves White again gives Black a chance. Even before the last move B - B 4 would have won with comparative ease, but the text move is a downright blunder, of which, fortunately for him, Black does not avail himself.

blocks.text: R x P would make it practically impossible for White to win, if he can win at all. White's best {169} continuation then would have been: 39 B - B 4, R - B 7; 40 R - Kt 5 ch, K - B 2; 41 B - Kt 8, P - R 6; 42 P - R 5, P - R 7; 43 B x P, R x B, and if there is a win it is very difficult to find it, as against 44 P - R 6, R - R 3 ! offers excellent chances for a draw.

blocks.text: As an end game, this is rather a sad exhibition for two masters. The redeeming feature of the game is Rubinstein's fine combination in the middle game, beginning with 14 B x Kt.

blocks.text: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE

blocks.text: (Havana, 1913)
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE

blocks.text: White: D. Janowski. Black: J. R. Capablanca.
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE

blocks.text: 1. P - Q 4                Kt - K B 3         2. Kt - K B 3             P - Q 3         3. B - Kt 5               Q Kt - Q 2         4. P - K 3                P - K 4         5. Kt - B 3               P - B 3         6. B - Q 3                B - K 2         7. Q - K 2                Q - R 4         8. O - O                  Kt - B 1         9. K R - Q 1              B - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE
GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE

blocks.text: At last Black is on his way to obtain full development. The idea of this irregular opening is mainly to throw White on his own resources. At the time the game was played, the system of defence was not as well known as the regular forms of the Queen's Pawn openings. Whether it is sound or not remains yet to be proved. Its good features are that it keeps the centre intact without creating any particular weakness, and that it gives plenty of opportunity for deep and concealed manoeuvring. The drawback is the long time it takes Black to develop his game. It is natural to suppose that
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 61/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE

blocks.text: White will employ that time to prepare a well-conceived attack, or that he will use the advantage of his development actually to prevent Black's complete development, or failing that, to obtain some definite material advantage.
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE

blocks.text: A very serious mistake. I considered castling, which was the right move, but desisted because I was afraid that by playing 13 B x Kt, P x B; 14 Kt - Kt 3, B - Kt 3; 15 Kt - B 5, White would obtain a winning position for the end game. Whether right or wrong this shows how closely related are all parts of the game, and consequently how one will influence the other.
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 12. ........               Kt x Kt

blocks.text: 13. B x B                  K x B        14. B x Kt                 B - Kt 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 13. B x B                  K x B        14. B x Kt                 B - Kt 3

blocks.text: Not good. The natural and proper move would have been Kt - K 3, in order to bring all the Black pieces into play. B x Kt at once was also good, as it would have relieved the pressure against Black's King's Pawn, and at the same time have simplified the game.
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 13. B x B                  K x B        14. B x Kt                 B - Kt 3

blocks.text: Here it is seen how failure to comply with the elementary logical reasons, that govern any given position, often brings the player into trouble. I was no doubt influenced in my choice of moves by the fear of B - B 5, which was a very threatening move.
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 13. B x B                  K x B        14. B x Kt                 B - Kt 3

blocks.text: 15. Q - B 4                Kt - K 3        16. P - Q Kt 4             Q - B 2        17. B x B                  R P x B        18. Q - K 4                K - B 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 13. B x B                  K x B        14. B x Kt                 B - Kt 3
GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 13. B x B                  K x B        14. B x Kt                 B - Kt 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 13. B x B                  K x B        14. B x Kt                 B - Kt 3
GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 19. R - Q 3

blocks.text: P - K R 4, to be followed by P - Kt 4, might have been a more vigorous way to carry on the attack. Black's weak point is unquestionably the Pawn at K 4, which he is compelled to defend with the King. The text move aims at doubling the Rooks, with the ultimate object of placing one of them at Q 6, supported by a Pawn at Q B 5, Black could only stop this by playing P - B 4 which would create a "hole" at Q 5; or by playing P - Kt 3, which would tie the Black Queen to the defence of the Q B P as well as the K P, which she already defends. Black, however, can meet all this by offering the exchange of Rooks, which destroys White's plans. For this reason P - K R 4 appears the proper way to carry on the attack.
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 19. R - Q 3
GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 19. ........               Q R - Q 1        20. Q R - Q 1              P - K Kt 4

blocks.text: This move is preparatory to P - K Kt 3, which would {173} make Black's position secure. Unfortunately for Black, he did not carry out his original plan.
blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 19. ........               Q R - Q 1        20. Q R - Q 1              P - K Kt 4

blocks.section_path: GAME 3. IRREGULAR DEFENCE > 21. P - B 4                R x R

blocks.text: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: (St. Petersburg, 1913)
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: White: J. R. Capablanca. Black: E. A. Snosko-Borovski.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: 1. P - Q 4                P - K 3         2. P - K 4                P - Q 4         3. Kt - Q B 3             Kt - K B 3         4. B - Kt 5               B - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: This constitutes the _McCutcheon Variation_. It aims at taking the initiative away from White. Instead {175} of defending, Black makes a counter demonstration on the Queen's side. It leads to highly interesting games.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: 5. P x P
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. P x P

blocks.text: At the time this game was played the variation 5 P - K 5 was in vogue, but I considered then, as I do now, the text move to be the stronger.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. P x P
GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. ........               Q x P

blocks.text: This is considered superior to P x P. It has for its object, as I said before, to take the initiative away from White by disrupting White's Queen's side. White, however, has more than ample compensation through his breaking up Black's King's side. It might be laid down as a principle of the opening that _the breaking up of the King's side is of more importance than a similar occurrence on the Queen's side_.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. ........               Q x P

blocks.text: 6. B x Kt                 B x Kt ch         7. P x B                  P x B         8. Kt - B 3               P - Q Kt 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. ........               Q x P

blocks.text: The plan of Black in this variation is to post his Bishop on the long diagonal so as to be able later on, in conjunction with the action of his Rooks along the open K Kt's file, to make a violent attack against White's King. It is, of course, expected that White will Castle on the King's side because of the broken-up condition of his Queen's side Pawns. {176}
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. ........               Q x P

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. ........               Q x P

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 63/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. ........               Q x P

blocks.text: 9. Q - Q 2                B - Kt 2        10. B - K 2                Kt - Q 2        11. P - B 4                Q - K B 4        12. O - O - O
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. ........               Q x P

blocks.text: An original idea, I believe, played for the first time in a similar position in a game against Mr. Walter Penn Shipley, of Philadelphia. My idea is that as there is no Black Bishop and because Black's pieces have been developed with a view to an attack on the King's side, it will be impossible for Black to take advantage of the apparently unprotected position of White's King. Two possibilities must be considered. Firstly: If Black Castles on the Queen's side, as in this game, it is evident that there is no danger of an attack. Secondly: If Black Castles on the King's side, White begins the attack first, taking advantage of the awkward position of Black's Queen. In addition to the attacking probabilities of the text move, White in one move brings his King into safety and brings one of his Rooks into play. Thus he gains several moves, "tempi" as they are called, which will serve him to develop whatever plan he may wish to evolve.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. ........               Q x P
GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. ........               Q x P

blocks.text: Unquestionably a mistake, overlooking White's fine {177} reply, but a careful examination will show that White already has the better position.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. ........               Q x P

blocks.text: 15. R - Q 3 !              K - Kt 1        16. K R - Q 1              Q - K B 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 15. R - Q 3 !              K - Kt 1        16. K R - Q 1              Q - K B 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 15. R - Q 3 !              K - Kt 1        16. K R - Q 1              Q - K B 4
GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. Kt - R 4

blocks.text: This move has been criticised because it puts the Knight out of the way for a few moves. But by forcing Q - K Kt 4; White gains a very important move with P - B 4, which not only consolidates his position, but also drives the Queen away, putting it out of the game for the moment. Certainly the Queen is far more valuable than the Knight, to say nothing of the time gained and the freedom of action obtained thereby for White's more important pieces.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. Kt - R 4
GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Q - K Kt 4        18. P - B 4                Q - Kt 2        19. B - B 3

blocks.text: {178} In such positions it is generally very advantageous to get rid of the Black Bishop controlling his Q R 3 and Q B 3, which form "holes" for White's pieces. The Bishop in such positions is of very great defensive value, hence the advantage of getting rid of it.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Q - K Kt 4        18. P - B 4                Q - Kt 2        19. B - B 3
GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Q - K Kt 4        18. P - B 4                Q - Kt 2        19. B - B 3

blocks.text: White threatened P - B 6 ch.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Q - K Kt 4        18. P - B 4                Q - Kt 2        19. B - B 3

blocks.text: 22. Kt - B 3               Q - B 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 22. Kt - B 3               Q - B 1

blocks.text: To prevent the Knight from moving to Q 6 via Q 2 and K 4 or Q B 4. It is self-evident that White has a great advantage of position.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 22. Kt - B 3               Q - B 1

blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 23. ........               P x P        24. Kt - B 4
GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 28. P - B 4

blocks.text: Kt - B 4 was the right move. I was, however, still looking for the "grand combination," and thought that the Pawn I would later on have at Q 6 would win the game. Black deserves great credit for the way in which he conducted this exceedingly difficult {180} defence. He could easily have gone wrong any number of times, but from move 22 onwards he always played the best move.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 28. P - B 4

blocks.text: 28. ........               P - K 4 !        29. Q - Kt 1               P - K 5        30. P x Kt                 P x R        31. P - Q 6                R - K 7        32. P - Q 7                R - B 7 ch        33. K - Kt 1               R - Kt 1 ch        34. Kt - Kt 3              Q - K 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 28. P - B 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 28. P - B 4

blocks.text: 35. R x P
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 35. R x P

blocks.text: The position is most interesting. I believe I lost here my last chance to win the game, and if that is true it would vindicate my judgment when, on move 28, I played P - B 4. The student can find out what would happen if White plays Q - Q 4 ! at once. I have gone over the following variations: 35 Q - Q 4, R x K R P (of course if R x B P, P - Q 8 wins); {181} 36 Q x Q P ! R - Q 1; 37 Q - R 6, K - Kt 1 best (if Q - Q 5 ch; K - R 1, K - Kt 1; R - Q Kt 1 wins); 38 Q x B P and White will at least have a draw.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 35. R x P
GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 35. R x P

blocks.text: There is nothing to be done against this simple move, since White cannot play Kt - Q 4, because Q - R 8 mates.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 35. R x P

blocks.text: 39. K - B 1                R x Q P        40. Kt - Q 4               R - K 8 ch             Resigns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 35. R x P

blocks.text: A very interesting battle.
blocks.section_path: GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 35. R x P
GAME 4. FRENCH DEFENCE > 35. R x P

blocks.text: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: (St. Petersburg, 1914)
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: White: Dr. E. Lasker. Black: J. R. Capablanca.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             Kt - Q B 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             Kt - Q B 3

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             Kt - Q B 3

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 65/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             Kt - Q B 3

blocks.text: 3. B - Kt 5               P - Q R 3         4. B x Kt
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 3. B - Kt 5               P - Q R 3         4. B x Kt

blocks.text: The object of this move is to bring about speedily a middle-game without Queens, in which White {182} has four Pawns to three on the King's side, while Black's superiority of Pawns on the other side is somewhat balanced by the fact that one of Black's Pawns is doubled. On the other hand, Black has the advantage of remaining with two Bishops while White has only one.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 3. B - Kt 5               P - Q R 3         4. B x Kt

blocks.text: 4. ........               Q P x B         5. P - Q 4                P x P         6. Q x P                  Q x Q         7. Kt x Q                 B - Q 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 3. B - Kt 5               P - Q R 3         4. B x Kt

blocks.text: Black's idea is to Castle on the King's side. His reason is that the King ought to remain on the weaker side to oppose later the advance of White's Pawns. Theoretically there is very much to be said in favour of this reasoning, but whether in practice that would be the best system would be rather difficult to prove. The student should notice that if now all the pieces were exchanged White would practically be a Pawn ahead, and would therefore have a won ending.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 3. B - Kt 5               P - Q R 3         4. B x Kt

blocks.text: 8. Kt - Q B 3             Kt - K 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 8. Kt - Q B 3             Kt - K 2

blocks.text: A perfectly sound form of development. In any other form adopted the Black Kt could not be developed either as quickly or as well. K 2 is the natural position for the Black Kt in this variation, in order not to obstruct Black's Pawns, and also, in some eventualities, in order to go to K Kt 3. There is {183} also the possibility of its going to Q 5 via Q B 3 after P - Q B 4.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 8. Kt - Q B 3             Kt - K 2

blocks.text: 9. O - O                  O - O        10. P - B 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 9. O - O                  O - O        10. P - B 4

blocks.text: This move I considered weak at the time, and I do still. It leaves the K P weak, unless it advances to K 5, and it also makes it possible for Black to pin the Kt by B - Q B 4.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 9. O - O                  O - O        10. P - B 4
GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 10. ........               R - K 1

blocks.text: Best. It threatens B - B 4; B - K 3, Kt - Q 4. It also prevents B - K 3 because of Kt - Q 4 or B 4.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 10. ........               R - K 1

blocks.text: 11. Kt - Kt 3              P - B 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 11. Kt - Kt 3              P - B 3

blocks.text: Preparatory to P - Q Kt 3, followed by P - Q B 4 and B - Kt 2 in conjunction with Kt - Kt 3, which would put White in great difficulties to meet the combined attack against the two centre Pawns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 11. Kt - Kt 3              P - B 3
GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 12. P - B 5

blocks.text: [Illustration] {184}
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 12. P - B 5

blocks.text: It has been wrongly claimed that this wins the game, but I would like nothing better than to have such a position again. It required several mistakes on my part finally to obtain a lost position.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 12. P - B 5
GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 12. ........               P - Q Kt 3        13. B - B 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 12. ........               P - Q Kt 3        13. B - B 4
GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 13. ........               B - Kt 2

blocks.text: Played against my better judgment. The right move of course was B x B. Dr. Lasker gives the following variation: 13...B x B; 14 R x B, P - B 4; 15 Q R - Q 1, B - Kt 2; 16 R - B 2, Q R - Q 1; 17 R x R, R x R; 18 R - Q 2, R x R; 19 Kt x R, and he claims that White has the best of it. But, as Niemzovitch pointed out immediately after the game, 16...Q R - Q 1 given in
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 13. ........               B - Kt 2

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 13. ........               B - Kt 2

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 66/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 13. ........               B - Kt 2

blocks.text: Dr. Lasker's variation, is not the best. If 16...Q R - B 1 ! then White will have great difficulty in drawing the game, {185} since there is no good way to stop Black from playing Kt - B 3, followed by Kt - K 4, threatening Kt - B 5. And should White attempt to meet this manoeuvre by withdrawing the Kt at Kt 3; then the Black Knight can go to Q 5, and the White Pawn at K 4 will be the object of the attack. Taking Dr. Lasker's variation, however, whatever advantage there might be disappears at once if Black plays 19...Kt - B 3, threatening Kt - Kt 5 and also Kt - Q 5, neither of which can be stopped. If White answers 20 Kt - Q 5, Kt - Q 5 for Black will at least draw. In fact, after 19...Kt - B 3 Black threatens so many things that it is difficult to see how White can prevent the loss of one or more Pawns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 13. ........               B - Kt 2

blocks.text: 14. B x B                  P x B        15. Kt - Q 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 14. B x B                  P x B        15. Kt - Q 4

blocks.text: It is a curious but true fact that I did not see this move when I played 13...B - Kt 2, otherwise I would have played the right move 13...B x B.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 14. B x B                  P x B        15. Kt - Q 4
GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 15. ........               Q R - Q 1

blocks.text: The game is yet far from lost, as against the entry of the Knight, Black can later on play P - B 4, followed by P - Q 4.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 15. ........               Q R - Q 1

blocks.text: 16. Kt - K 6               R - Q 2        17. Q R - Q 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 16. Kt - K 6               R - Q 2        17. Q R - Q 1
GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 16. Kt - K 6               R - Q 2        17. Q R - Q 1

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 16. Kt - K 6               R - Q 2        17. Q R - Q 1

blocks.text: I now was on the point of playing P - B 4, to be followed by P - Q 4, which I thought would give me a draw, but suddenly I became ambitious and thought that I could play the text move, 17...Kt - B 1, and later on sacrifice the exchange for the Knight at K 6, winning a Pawn for it, and leaving White's K P still weaker. I intended to carry this plan either before or after playing P - K Kt 4 as the circumstances demanded. Now let us analyse: 17...P - B 4. If 18 Kt - Q 5, B x Kt; 19 P x B, P - Q Kt 4; and a careful analysis will show that Black has nothing to fear. Black's plan in this case would be to work his Kt around to K 4, via Q B 1, Q Kt 3, and Q B 5 or Q 2. Again, 17...P - B 4; 18 R - B 2, P - Q 4; 19 P x P, B x P; 20 Kt x B (best, since if R (B 2) - Q 2, B x Kt give Black the advantage), R x Kt; 21 R x R, Kt x R; and there is no good reason why Black should lose.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 16. Kt - K 6               R - Q 2        17. Q R - Q 1
GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 16. Kt - K 6               R - Q 2        17. Q R - Q 1

blocks.text: Once more changing my plan and this time without any good reason. Had I now played R x Kt; P x R ch, R x P; as I intended to do when I went back with the Knight to B 1, I doubt very much if White would have been able to win the game. At least it would have been extremely difficult.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 16. Kt - K 6               R - Q 2        17. Q R - Q 1

blocks.text: 22. K - B 2                R - R 2        23. P - Kt 4               P - R 3        24. R - Q 3                P - Q R 4        25. P - K R 4              P x P        26. P x P                  R (R 2) - K 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 16. Kt - K 6               R - Q 2        17. Q R - Q 1

blocks.text: This, of course, has no object now. Black, with a bad game, flounders around for a move. It would have been better to play R - R 6 to keep the open file, and at the same time to threaten to come out with the Knight at Kt 3 and B 5.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 16. Kt - K 6               R - Q 2        17. Q R - Q 1

blocks.text: 27. K - B 3                R - Kt 1        28. K - B 4                P - Kt 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 27. K - B 3                R - Kt 1        28. K - B 4                P - Kt 3

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 27. K - B 3                R - Kt 1        28. K - B 4                P - Kt 3

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 67/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 27. K - B 3                R - Kt 1        28. K - B 4                P - Kt 3

blocks.text: Again bad. White's last two moves were weak, since the White King does nothing here. He should have played his Rook to Kt 3 on the 27th move. Black now should have played P - Kt 4 ch. After missing this chance White has it all his own way, and finishes the game most accurately, and Black becomes more {188} helpless with each move. The game needs no further comment, excepting that my play throughout was of an altogether irresolute character. When a plan is made, it must be carried out if at all possible. Regarding the play of White, I consider his 10th and 12th moves were very weak; he played well after that up to the 27th move, which was bad, as well as his 28th move. The rest of his play was good, probably perfect.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 27. K - B 3                R - Kt 1        28. K - B 4                P - Kt 3

blocks.text: 29. R - Kt 3               P - Kt 4 ch        30. K - B 3                Kt - Kt 3        31. P x P                  R P x P        32. R - R 3                R - Q 2        33. K - Kt 3 !             K - K 1        34. Q R - K R 1            B - Kt 2        35. P - K 5                Q P x P        36. Kt - K 4               Kt - Q 4        37. Kt (K 6) - B 5         B - B 1        38. Kt x R                 B x Kt        39. R - R 7                R - B 1        40. R - R 1                K - Q 1        41. R - R 8 ch             B - B 1        42. Kt - B 5               Resigns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 27. K - B 3                R - Kt 1        28. K - B 4                P - Kt 3
GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 27. K - B 3                R - Kt 1        28. K - B 4                P - Kt 3
GAME 5. RUY LOPEZ > 27. K - B 3                R - Kt 1        28. K - B 4                P - Kt 3

blocks.text: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: (Rice Memorial Tournament, 1916)
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: White: O. Chajes. Black: J. R. Capablanca.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 3         2. P - Q 4                P - Q 4         3. Kt - Q B 3             Kt - K B 3         4. B - Kt 5               B - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: Of all the variations of the French Defence I like this best, because it gives Black more chances to obtain the initiative.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. P - K 5

blocks.text: Though I consider P x P the best move, there is much to be said in favour of this move, but not of the variation as a whole, which White adopted in this game.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. P - K 5

blocks.text: 5. ........               P - K R 3         6. B - Q 2                B x Kt         7. P x B                  Kt - K 5         8. Q - Kt 4               K - B 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. P - K 5

blocks.text: The alternative, P - K Kt 3; leaves Black's King's side very weak. White by playing P - K R 4 would force Black to play P - K R 4; and later, on White's Bishop by going to Q 3, would threaten the weakened K Kt P. By the text move Black gives up Castling, but gains time for an attack against White's centre and Queen's side. {190}
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 5. P - K 5

blocks.text: 9. B - B 1                P - Q B 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 9. B - B 1                P - Q B 4

blocks.text: Threatening Q - R 4 and stopping thereby White's threat of B - R 3. It demonstrates that White's last move was a complete loss of time and merely weakened his position.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 9. B - B 1                P - Q B 4
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 10. B - Q 3                Q - R 4

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 10. B - Q 3                Q - R 4

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 68/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 10. B - Q 3                Q - R 4

blocks.text: 11. Kt - K 2               P x P        12. O - O                  P x P        13. B x Kt                 P x B        14. Q x P                  Kt - B 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 10. B - Q 3                Q - R 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 10. B - Q 3                Q - R 4

blocks.text: Black has come out of the opening with a Pawn to the good. His development, however, has suffered somewhat, and there are Bishops of opposite colour, so that it cannot be said as yet, that Black has a won game; but he has certainly the best of the position, because, besides being a Pawn to the good, he threatens White's K P, which must of course be {191} defended, and this in turn will give him the opportunity to post his Knight at Q 4 via K 2. When the Black Knight is posted at Q 4, the Bishop will be developed to B 3 via Q 2, as soon as the opportunity presents itself, and it will be Black that will then have the initiative, and can consequently decide the course of the game.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 10. B - Q 3                Q - R 4
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 15. R - Q 1

blocks.text: To prevent Kt - K 2; which would be answered by Kt x P, or still better by B - R 3. The move, however, is strategically wrong, since by bringing his pieces to the Queen's side, White loses any chance he might have of making a determined attack on the King's side before Black is thoroughly prepared for it.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 15. R - Q 1
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 15. ........               P - K Kt 3        16. P - B 4                K - Kt 2        17. B - K 3

blocks.text: Better would have been P - Q R 4, in order to play B - R 3. The White B would be much better posted on the open diagonal than here, where it acts purely on the defensive.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 15. ........               P - K Kt 3        16. P - B 4                K - Kt 2        17. B - K 3
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Kt - K 2        18. B - B 2                Kt - Q 4

blocks.text: This Knight completely paralyses the attack, as it dominates the whole situation, and there is no way to dislodge it. Behind it Black can quietly develop his pieces. The game can now be said to be won for Black strategically. {192}
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Kt - K 2        18. B - B 2                Kt - Q 4

blocks.text: 19. R - Q 3                B - Q 2        20. Kt - Q 4               Q R - Q B 1        21. R - Kt 3               K - R 2        22. P - K R 4              K R - Kt 1        23. P - R 5                Q - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Kt - K 2        18. B - B 2                Kt - Q 4

blocks.text: In order to pin the Knight and be ready to come back to either K 2 or B 1. Also to prevent Q R - Kt 1. In reality nearly all these precautions are unnecessary, since White's attack amounts to nothing. Probably Black should have left aside all these considerations, and played Q - R 5 now, in order to follow it up with P - B 4, as he did later, but under less favourable circumstances.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Kt - K 2        18. B - B 2                Kt - Q 4
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 24. R - R 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 24. R - R 3
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 24. ........               P - B 4

blocks.text: Not the best, as White will soon prove. Q - B 1 would have avoided everything, but Black wants to assume the initiative at once and plunges into {193} complications. However, as will soon be seen, the move is not a losing one by any means.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 24. ........               P - B 4

blocks.text: 25. P x P e.p.             Kt x P (B 3)        26. P x P ch               R x P
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 25. P x P e.p.             Kt x P (B 3)        26. P x P ch               R x P

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 25. P x P e.p.             Kt x P (B 3)        26. P x P ch               R x P

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 69/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 25. P x P e.p.             Kt x P (B 3)        26. P x P ch               R x P

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 25. P x P e.p.             Kt x P (B 3)        26. P x P ch               R x P

blocks.text: 27. R x P ch
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 27. R x P ch

blocks.text: This wins the Queen.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 27. R x P ch

blocks.text: 27. ........               K x R        28. Kt - B 5 ch            P x Kt        29. Q x Q
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 27. ........               K x R        28. Kt - B 5 ch            P x Kt        29. Q x Q

blocks.text: [Illustration] {194}
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 27. ........               K x R        28. Kt - B 5 ch            P x Kt        29. Q x Q

blocks.text: The position looks most interesting. I thought it would be possible to get up such an attack against the White King as to make it impossible for him to hold out much longer, but I was wrong, unless it could have been done by playing B - B 3 first, forcing P - Kt 3 and then playing K - R 4. I followed a similar plan, but lost a very important move by playing Q R - K Kt 1; which gave White time to play R - Q 1. I am convinced, however, that B - B 3 at once was the right move. White would be forced to play P - Kt 3, and Black would reply with either K - R 4; as already indicated, which looks the best (the plan, of course, is to play R - K R 1; and follow it up with K - Kt 5; threatening mate, or some other move according to circumstances. In some cases, of course, it will be better first to play K - Kt 5), or Kt - K 5, which will at least give him a draw. There are so many possibilities in this position that it would be impossible to give them all. It will be worth the reader's time to go carefully through the lines of play indicated above.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 27. ........               K x R        28. Kt - B 5 ch            P x Kt        29. Q x Q
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 29. ........               Q R - K Kt 1

blocks.text: As stated B - B 3 was the best move.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 29. ........               Q R - K Kt 1
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 30. P - Kt 3               B - B 3        31. R - Q 1                K - R 4

blocks.text: The plan, of course, as explained above, is to go to Kt 5 in due time and threaten mate at K R 8, but it is now too late, the White Rook having come in {195} time to prevent the manoeuvre. Instead of the text move, therefore, Black should have played Kt - K 5; which would have given him a draw at the very least. After the text moves the tables are turned. It is now White who has the upper hand, and Black who has to fight for a draw.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 30. P - Kt 3               B - B 3        31. R - Q 1                K - R 4
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 32. R - Q 6                B - K 5

blocks.text: Kt - K 5 was still the right move, and probably the last chance Black had to draw against White's best play.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 32. R - Q 6                B - K 5

blocks.text: 33. Q x B P                Kt - Q 4        34. R x R                  K x R
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 33. Q x B P                Kt - Q 4        34. R x R                  K x R

blocks.text: Kt x Q; R x R, Kt x P was no better.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 33. Q x B P                Kt - Q 4        34. R x R                  K x R

blocks.text: 35. Q - K 5                K - B 2        36. P - B 4                R - K 1        37. Q - Kt 2               Kt - B 3        38. B - Q 4                R - K R 1        39. Q - Kt 5               R - R 8 ch        40. K - B 2                P - R 3        41. Q - Kt 6               R - R 7 ch        42. K - K 1                Kt - Q 2        43. Q - Q 6                B - B 3        44. P - Kt 4               P x P        45. P - K B 5              R - R 8 ch        46. K - Q 2                K - K 1        47. P - B 6                R - R 2        48. Q - K 6 ch             K - B 1        49. B - K 3                R - B 2        50. B - R 6 ch             K - Kt 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 33. Q x B P                Kt - Q 4        34. R x R                  K x R

blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 33. Q x B P                Kt - Q 4        34. R x R                  K x R
GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 33. Q x B P                Kt - Q 4        34. R x R                  K x R

blocks.text: Most players will be wondering, as the spectators did, why I did not resign. The reason is that while I knew the game to be lost, I was hoping for the following variation, which Chajes came very near playing: 51 Q x P ch, K - R 2; 52 Q - R 5, R x P; 53 B - Kt 5 ch, K - Kt 2; 54 B x R ch, K x B; and while White has a won game it is by no means easy. If the reader does not believe it, let him take the White pieces against a master and see what happens. My opponent, who decided to take no chances, played 51 B - Kt 7, and finally won as shown below.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 33. Q x B P                Kt - Q 4        34. R x R                  K x R

blocks.text: 51. B - Kt 7               P - Kt 6        52. K - K2                 P - Kt 7        53. K - B 2                Kt - B 1        54. Q - Kt 4               Kt - Q 2        55. K - Kt 1               P - R 4        56. P - R 4                B x P        57. Q - R 3                R x P        58. B x R                  Kt x B        59. Q x P ch               K - B 1        60. Q x P
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 33. Q x B P                Kt - Q 4        34. R x R                  K x R

blocks.text: and after a very few more moves Black resigned.
blocks.section_path: GAME 6. FRENCH DEFENCE > 33. Q x B P                Kt - Q 4        34. R x R                  K x R

blocks.text: A very fine game on Chajes' part from move 25 on, for while Black, having the best of the position, missed several chances, White, on the other hand, missed none.

blocks.text: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: (San Sebastian, 1911)
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: White: J. R. Capablanca. Black: A. Burn
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             Kt - Q B 3         3. B - Kt 5               P - Q R 3         4. B - R 4                Kt - B 3         5. P - Q 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: This is a very solid development, to which I was much addicted at the time, because of my ignorance of the multiple variations of the openings.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ
GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 5. ........               P - Q 3         6. P - B 3                B - K 2

blocks.text: In this variation there is the alternative of developing this Bishop via Kt 2, after P - K Kt 3.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 5. ........               P - Q 3         6. P - B 3                B - K 2

blocks.text: 7. Q Kt - Q 2             O - O         8. Kt - B 1               P - Q Kt 4         9. B - B 2                P - Q 4        10. Q - K 2                P x P        11. P x P                  B - Q B 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 5. ........               P - Q 3         6. P - B 3                B - K 2

blocks.text: Evidently to make room for the Queen at K 2, but I do not think the move advisable at this stage. B - K 3 is a more natural and effective move. It develops a piece and threatens B - B 5, which would have to be stopped.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 5. ........               P - Q 3         6. P - B 3                B - K 2

blocks.text: 12. B - Kt 5               B - K 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 12. B - Kt 5               B - K 3

blocks.text: {198} Now it is not so effective, because White's Q B is out, and the Knight, in going to K 3 to defend the square Q B 4, does not block the Q B.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 12. B - Kt 5               B - K 3

blocks.text: 13. Kt - K 3               R - K 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 13. Kt - K 3               R - K 1

blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 13. Kt - K 3               R - K 1

blocks.text: 14. O - O                  Q - K 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 14. O - O                  Q - K 2

blocks.text: This is bad. Black's game was already not good. He probably had no choice but to take the Knight with the Bishop before making this move.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 14. O - O                  Q - K 2

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 14. O - O                  Q - K 2

blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 15. Kt - Q 5               B x Kt        16. P x B                  Kt - Kt 1

blocks.text: in order to bring it to Q 2, to support the other Knight and also his King's Pawn. White, however, does not allow time for this, and by taking advantage of his superior position is able to win a Pawn.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 15. Kt - Q 5               B x Kt        16. P x B                  Kt - Kt 1

blocks.text: 17. P - Q R 4              P - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 17. P - Q R 4              P - Kt 5

blocks.text: Since he had no way to prevent the loss of a Pawn, he should have given it up where it is, and played Q Kt - Q 2, in order to make his position more solid. {199} The text move not only loses a Pawn, but leaves Black's game very much weakened.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 17. P - Q R 4              P - Kt 5

blocks.text: 18. P x P                  B x P        19. B x Kt                 Q x B        20. Q - K 4                B - Q 3        21. Q x P ch               K - B 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 17. P - Q R 4              P - Kt 5

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 17. P - Q R 4              P - Kt 5

blocks.text: With a Pawn more and all his pieces ready for action, while Black is still backward in development, it only remains for White to drive home his advantage before Black can come out with his pieces, in which case, by using the open K R file, Black might be able to start a strong attack against White's King. White is able by his next move to eliminate all danger.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 17. P - Q R 4              P - Kt 5

blocks.text: 22. Kt - R 4               Q - R 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 22. Kt - R 4               Q - R 3

blocks.text: This is practically forced. Black could not play P - Kt 3 because of B x P, and White meanwhile threatened Q - R 8 ch followed by Kt - B 5 ch and Q x P. {200}
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 22. Kt - R 4               Q - R 3

blocks.text: 23. Q x Q                  P x Q        24. Kt - B 5               P - K R 4        25. B - Q 1                Kt - Q 2        26. B x P                  Kt - B 3        27. B - K 2                Kt x P        28. K R - Q 1              Kt - B 5        29. B - B 4                K R - Q 1        30. P - R 4                P - R 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 22. Kt - R 4               Q - R 3

blocks.text: Black must lose time assuring the safety of this Pawn.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 22. Kt - R 4               Q - R 3

blocks.text: 31. P - Kt 3               Kt - K 3        32. B x Kt                 P x B        33. Kt - K 3               K R - Kt 1        34. Kt - B 4               K - K 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 22. Kt - R 4               Q - R 3

blocks.text: Black fights a hopeless battle. He is two Pawns down for all practical purposes, and the Pawns he has are isolated and have to be defended by pieces.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 22. Kt - R 4               Q - R 3

blocks.text: 35. Q R - B 1              R - R 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 35. Q R - B 1              R - R 2

blocks.text: White threatened Kt x B, followed by R - B 7 ch.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 35. Q R - B 1              R - R 2

P - Kt 5               R - R 3        44. P - R 5                R x Kt        45. P x R                  R - B 3        46. P - Kt 6               Resigns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 7. RUY LOPEZ > 35. Q R - B 1              R - R 2
