blocks.text: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME

blocks.text: (Berlin 1913)
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME

blocks.text: White: J. Mieses. Black: J. R. Capablanca.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. P - Q 4                P x P         3. Q x P                  Kt - Q B 3         4. Q - K 3                Kt - B 3         5. Kt - Q B 3             B - Kt 5         6. B - Q 2                O - O         7. O - O - O              R - K 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME

blocks.text: In this position, instead of the text move, P - Q 3 is often played in order to develop the Q B. My idea was to exert sufficient pressure against the K P to win it, and thus gain a material advantage, which would, at least, compensate whatever slight advantage of position White might have. The plan, I think, is quite feasible, my subsequent difficulties being due to faulty execution of the plan.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME

blocks.text: 8. Q - Kt 3               Kt x P         9. Kt x Kt                R x Kt        10. B - K B 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 8. Q - Kt 3               Kt x P         9. Kt x Kt                R x Kt        10. B - K B 4
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 8. Q - Kt 3               Kt x P         9. Kt x Kt                R x Kt        10. B - K B 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 8. Q - Kt 3               Kt x P         9. Kt x Kt                R x Kt        10. B - K B 4
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 10. ........               Q - B 3

blocks.text: White's threat to regain the Pawn was merely with the idea of gaining time to develop his pieces. Black could have played P - Q 3; opening the way for his Q B, when would have followed, 11 B - Q 3, R - K 1; 12 Kt - B 3, and White would soon start a powerful direct attack against Black's King. With the text move Black aims at taking the initiative away from White in accordance with the principles laid down in this book.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 10. ........               Q - B 3
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 11. Kt - R 3

blocks.text: If B x P, P - Q 3; and White's Bishop would be completely shut off, and could only be extricated, if at all, with serious loss of position. The text move aims at quick development to keep the initiative.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 11. Kt - R 3
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 11. ........               P - Q 3

blocks.text: This now is not only a developing move, but it also threatens to win a piece by B x Kt. {203}
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 11. ........               P - Q 3

blocks.text: 12. B - Q 3                Kt - Q 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 12. B - Q 3                Kt - Q 5

blocks.text: This complicates the game unnecessarily. R - K 1; was simple, and perfectly safe.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 12. B - Q 3                Kt - Q 5
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 13. B - K 3

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 13. B - K 3

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 73/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 13. B - K 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 13. B - K 3
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 13. ........               B - Kt 5

blocks.text: This is a serious mistake. The position was most interesting, and though in appearance dangerous for Black, not so in reality. The right move would have been 13...R - Kt 5, when we would have 14 B x Kt, R x B; 15 P - Q B 3, B x P; 16 P x B, R - K Kt 5; 17 Q - K 3 (best), Q x P ch; 18 B - B 2, Q x Q; 19 P x Q, R x P, and Black has the best of the game with four Pawns for a Knight, besides the fact that all the White Pawns are isolated.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 13. ........               B - Kt 5

blocks.text: 14. Kt - Kt 5 !            R x B
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 14. Kt - Kt 5 !            R x B

blocks.text: There was nothing better.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 14. Kt - Kt 5 !            R x B

blocks.text: 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch

blocks.text: 16. B x Kt !               R x B        17. Kt - K 4 !             R x Kt        18. Q x R                  Q - Kt 4 ch        19. P - K B 4              Q - Kt 4        20. P - B 3                B - B 4        21. K R - K 1              Q - B 3        22. R - Q 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch

blocks.text: Q x Q would have given White a decided advantage, enough to win with proper play. Mieses, however, feared the difficulties of an ending where, while having the exchange, he would be a Pawn minus. He preferred to keep the Queens on the board and keep up the attack. At first sight, and even after careful thought, there seems to be no objection to his plan; but in truth such is not the case. From this point the game will gradually improve in Black's favour until, with the exchange ahead, White is lost. {205}
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch

blocks.text: My plan for the moment is very simple. It will consist in bringing my Bishop around to B 3. Then I shall try to paralyse White's attack against my King by playing P - K R 3, and also prevent White from ever playing P - K Kt 5. Once my King is safe from attack I shall begin to advance my Queen's side Pawns, where there are four to three; and that advantage, coupled with the enormous attacking power of my Bishop at B 3, will at least assure me an even chance of success.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch

blocks.text: 25. Q - B 3                B - K 2        26. Q R - K 2              B - B 3        27. Q - R 5                P - K R 3        28. P - K Kt 4             K - R 2 !
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch

blocks.text: {206} To prevent P - K R 4, which I would answer with P - K Kt 3, winning the Queen. It can now be considered that my King is safe from attack. White will have to withdraw his Queen via R 3, and Black can use the time to begin his advance on the Queen's side.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 15. Q x B !                Kt - K 7 ch
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 29. K - Kt 1               R - Q 1        30. R - Q 1                P - B 4

blocks.text: Notice that, on assuming the defensive, White has placed his Rooks correctly from the point of view of strategy. They are both on white squares free from the possible attack of the Black Bishop.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 29. K - Kt 1               R - Q 1        30. R - Q 1                P - B 4

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 29. K - Kt 1               R - Q 1        30. R - Q 1                P - B 4

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 74/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 29. K - Kt 1               R - Q 1        30. R - Q 1                P - B 4
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 31. Q - R 3                Q - R 5

blocks.text: This gains time by attacking the Rook and holding the White Q at R 3 for the moment, on account of the K Kt P. Besides, the Queen must be in the middle of the fray now that the attack has to be brought home. White has actually more value in material, and therefore Black must utilise everything at his command in order to succeed.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 31. Q - R 3                Q - R 5

blocks.text: 32. R (K2) - Q 2           Q - K 5 ch        33. K - R 1                P - Q Kt 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 32. R (K2) - Q 2           Q - K 5 ch        33. K - R 1                P - Q Kt 4

blocks.text: threatening P - Kt 5; which would open the line of action of the Bishop and also secure a passed Pawn.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 32. R (K2) - Q 2           Q - K 5 ch        33. K - R 1                P - Q Kt 4

blocks.text: 34. Q - Kt 2               Q - R 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 34. Q - Kt 2               Q - R 5

blocks.text: indirectly defending the Q P, which White cannot take on account of Q x R ch.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 34. Q - Kt 2               Q - R 5
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 34. Q - Kt 2               Q - R 5

blocks.text: The attack increases in force as it is gradually brought home directly against the King. The position now is most interesting and extremely difficult. It is doubtful if there is any valid defence against Black's best play. The variations are numerous and difficult.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 34. Q - Kt 2               Q - R 5

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 34. Q - Kt 2               Q - R 5

blocks.text: 36. P x P                  Q x P
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 36. P x P                  Q x P

blocks.text: Black has now a passed Pawn, and his Bishop exerts great pressure. White cannot very well play now 37 R x P because of R x R; 38 R x R, B x P; and White could not take the Bishop because Q - K 5 ch would win the Rook, leaving Black a clear passed Pawn ahead.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 36. P x P                  Q x P

blocks.text: 37. P - Q R 3              Q - R 5 !        38. R x P                  R - Q Kt 1        39. R (Q 1) - Q 2          P - B 5        40. Q - Kt 3               R - Kt 6        41. Q - Q 6
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 36. P x P                  Q x P
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 36. P x P                  Q x P

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 36. P x P                  Q x P
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 41. ........               P - B 6

blocks.text: B x P would also win, which shows that White's game is altogether gone. In these cases, however, it is not the prettiest move that should be played, but the most effective one, the move that will make your opponent resign soonest.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 41. ........               P - B 6

blocks.text: 42. R - Q B 2              P x P        43. R - Q 3                Q - K 5 !        44. R - Q 1                R - Q B 6             Resigns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 41. ........               P - B 6

blocks.text: Of course White must play Q - Q 2, and Black then plays R x P.
blocks.section_path: GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 41. ........               P - B 6
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 41. ........               P - B 6
GAME 8. CENTRE GAME > 41. ........               P - B 6

blocks.text: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: (Berlin, 1913)
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: White: J. R. Capablanca. Black: R. Teichmann.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 75/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4         2. Kt - K B 3             Kt - K B 3         3. P - B 4                P - K 3         4. B - Kt 5               B - K 2         5. Kt - B 3               Q Kt - Q 2         6. P - K 3                O - O         7. R - B 1                P - Q Kt 3         8. P x P                  P x P         9. B - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: An invention of my own, I believe. I played it on the spur of the moment simply to change the normal course of the game. Generally the Bishop goes to Q 3, or to R 6, after Q - R 4. The text move is in the nature of an ordinary developing move, and as it violates no principle it cannot be bad.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: If P x P; K R - Q 1, and White would play to win one of Black's centre Pawns. The drawback to the {210} text move is that it leaves Black's Q P isolated, and consequently weak and subject to attack.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: 14. K R - Q 1              Kt x B
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 14. K R - Q 1              Kt x B

blocks.text: The alternative would have been 14...P - Kt 4; 15 B - B 2, P - Kt 5; 16 Kt - Q R 4, Kt (B 4) - K 5.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 14. K R - Q 1              Kt x B

blocks.text: 15. Kt x Kt                P - Kt 4        16. R x R                  Q x R        17. Kt - B 3               Q - B 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 14. K R - Q 1              Kt x B

blocks.text: Black aims at the exchange of Queens in order to remain with two Bishops for the ending, but in this position such a course is a mistake, because the Bishop at Kt 2 is inactive and cannot come into the game by any means, unless Black gives up the isolated Queen's Pawn which the Bishop must defend.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 14. K R - Q 1              Kt x B
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. Kt - Q 4

blocks.text: Not, of course, R - Q 4, because of Q x Q; Kt x Q, R - B 1; and there would be no good way to prevent R - B 7.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. Kt - Q 4
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. ........               Q x Q        19. Kt (B 3) x Q !

blocks.text: Notice the co-ordination of the Knights' moves. They are manoeuvred chain-like, so to speak, in order to maintain one of them, either at Q 4 or ready to go there. Now White threatens to take the open file, and therefore forces Black's next move.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. ........               Q x Q        19. Kt (B 3) x Q !
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 19. ........               R - B 1
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 19. ........               R - B 1

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 19. ........               R - B 1

blocks.text: The student should examine this position carefully. There seems to be no particular danger, yet, as White will demonstrate, Black may be said to be lost. If the game is not altogether lost, the defence is at least of the most difficult kind; indeed, I must confess that I can see no adequate defence against White's next move.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 19. ........               R - B 1
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 20. Kt - B 5 !             K - B 1

blocks.text: If 20...B - Q 1; 21 Kt - Q 6, R - B 2; 22 Kt x B, R x Kt; 23 B x Kt, B x B; 24 R x P, R - B 2; 25 R - Q 2, and White is a Pawn ahead. If 20...B moves
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 20. Kt - B 5 !             K - B 1

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 20. Kt - B 5 !             K - B 1

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 76/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 20. Kt - B 5 !             K - B 1

blocks.text: anywhere else, then B x Kt, doubling the K B P and isolating all of Black's King's side Pawns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 20. Kt - B 5 !             K - B 1

blocks.text: 21. Kt x B                 K x Kt        22. Kt - Q 4               P - Kt 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 21. Kt x B                 K x Kt        22. Kt - Q 4               P - Kt 3

blocks.text: This is practically forced, as White threatened Kt - B 5 ch. Notice that the Black Knight is pinned in such a way that no relief can be afforded except by giving up the K R P or abandoning the open file {212} with the Rook, which would be disastrous, as White would immediately sieze it.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 21. Kt x B                 K x Kt        22. Kt - Q 4               P - Kt 3
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 23. P - B 3 !

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 23. P - B 3 !
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 23. ........               P - R 3

blocks.text: Black could do nothing else except mark time with his Rook along the open file, since as soon as he moved away White would take it. White, on the other hand, threatens to march up with his King to K 5 via K B 2, K Kt 3, K B 4, after having, of course, prepared the way. Hence, Black's best chance was to give up a Pawn, as in the text, in order to free his Knight.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 23. ........               P - R 3

blocks.text: 24. B x P                  Kt - Q 2        25. P - K R 4              Kt - B 4        26. B - B 4                Kt - K 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 23. ........               P - R 3

blocks.text: Black exchanges Knights to remain with Bishops of {213} opposite colours, which gives him the best chance to draw.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 23. ........               P - R 3

blocks.text: 27. Kt x Kt                K x Kt
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 27. Kt x Kt                K x Kt

blocks.text: 27...P x Kt would be worse, as White would then be able to post his Bishop at K 5.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 27. Kt x Kt                K x Kt

blocks.text: 28. R - Q 2                R - K R 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 28. R - Q 2                R - K R 1

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 28. R - Q 2                R - K R 1

blocks.text: Black wants to force B - Kt 3. P - K Kt 3 would be bad, on account of P - Q 5; which would get the Black Bishop into the game, even though White could answer P - K 4. The text move is, however, weak, as will soon be seen. His best chance was to play P - Kt 5; and follow it up with P - R 4 and B - R 3. White meanwhile could play P - Kt 4 and R 5, obtaining a passed Pawn, which, with proper play, should win.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 28. R - Q 2                R - K R 1

blocks.text: 29. R - Q B 2 !            R - Q B 1        30. R x R                  B x R
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 29. R - Q B 2 !            R - Q B 1        30. R x R                  B x R

blocks.text: There are now Bishops of opposite colour, but nevertheless White has an easily-won game. {214}
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 29. R - Q B 2 !            R - Q B 1        30. R x R                  B x R
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 31. K - B 2

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 31. K - B 2
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 31. ........               P - Q 5

blocks.text: Practically forced. Otherwise the White King would march up to Q 4 and then to B 5 and win Black's Queen's side Pawns. If Black attempted to stop this by putting his King at Q B 3 then the White King would enter through K 5 into Black's King's side and win just as easily.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 31. ........               P - Q 5

blocks.text: 32. P x P                  K - Q 4        33. K - K 3                B - K 3        34. K - Q 3                K - B 3        35. P - Q R 3              B - B 5 ch        36. K - K 3                B - K 3        37. B - R 6
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 31. ........               P - Q 5

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 31. ........               P - Q 5

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 77/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 31. ........               P - Q 5

blocks.text: It is better not to hurry P - K Kt 4 because of P - B 4; for although White could win in any case, it would take longer. Now the White King threatens to help by going in through K B 4 after posting the Bishop {215} at Kt 7, where it not only protects the Q P, but indirectly also the Q Kt P.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 31. ........               P - Q 5
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 37. ........               K - Q 4        38. B - Kt 7               Resigns.

blocks.text: The student ought to have realised by this time the enormous importance of playing well every kind of ending. In this game again, practically from the opening, White aimed at nothing but the isolation of Black's Q P. Once he obtained that, he tried for and obtained, fortunately, another advantage of position elsewhere which translated itself into the material advantage of a Pawn. Then by accurate playing in the ending he gradually forced home his advantage. This ending has the merit of having been played against one of the finest players in the world.
blocks.section_path: GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 37. ........               K - Q 4        38. B - Kt 7               Resigns.
GAME 9. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 37. ........               K - Q 4        38. B - Kt 7               Resigns.

blocks.text: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE

blocks.text: (St. Petersburg, 1914)
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE

blocks.text: White: J. R. Capablanca. Black: F. J. Marshall
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             Kt - K B 3         3. Kt x P                 P - Q 3         4. Kt - K B 3             Kt x P         5. Q - K 2                Q - K 2         6. P - Q 3                Kt - K B 3         7. B - Kt 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE

blocks.text: {216} Played by Morphy, and a very fine move. The point is that should Black exchange Queens he will be a move behind in development and consequently will get a cramped game if White plays accurately.
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE
GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 7. ........               B - K 3

blocks.text: Marshall thought at the time that this was the best move and consequently played it in preference to Q x Q ch.
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 7. ........               B - K 3

blocks.text: 8. Kt - B 3               P - K R 3         9. B x Kt                 Q x B        10. P - Q 4                B - K 2        11. Q - Kt 5 ch            Kt - Q 2        12. B - Q 3 !
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 7. ........               B - K 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 7. ........               B - K 3

blocks.text: It is now time to examine the result of the opening. On White's side we find the minor pieces well posted and the Queen out in a somewhat odd place, it is true, but safe from attack and actually attacking a Pawn. {217} White is also ready to Castle. White's position is evidently free from danger and his pieces can easily manoeuvre.
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 7. ........               B - K 3

blocks.text: On Black's side the first thing we notice is that he has retained both his Bishops, unquestionably an advantage; but on the other hand we find his pieces bunched together too much, and the Queen in danger of being attacked without having any good square to go to. The Bishop at K 2 has no freedom and it blocks the Queen, which, in its turn, blocks the Bishop. Besides, Black cannot Castle on the King's side because Q x P, R - Kt 1; Q - K 4 threatening mate, wins a Pawn. Nor can he Castle on the Queen's side because Q - R 5 would put Black's game in imminent danger, since he cannot play P - R 3 because of B x P; nor can he play K - Kt 1 because of Kt - Kt 5. Consequently we must conclude that the opening is all in White's favour.
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 7. ........               B - K 3

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 7. ........               B - K 3

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 78/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 7. ........               B - K 3
GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 12. ........               P - Kt 4

blocks.text: To make room for his Queen, threatening also P - Kt 5.
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 12. ........               P - Kt 4

blocks.text: 13. P - K R 3              O - O
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 13. P - K R 3              O - O

blocks.text: giving up a Pawn in an attempt to free his game and take the initiative. It was difficult for him to find a move, as White threatened Kt - K 4, and should Black go with the Queen to Kt 2, then P - Q 5, B - B 4; Kt x P ch, followed by B x B. {218}
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 13. P - K R 3              O - O

blocks.text: 14. Q x P                  Q R - Kt 1        15. Q - K 4                Q - Kt 2        16. P - Q Kt 3             P - Q B 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 13. P - K R 3              O - O

blocks.text: In order to break up White's centre and bring his Knight to B 4 and thus lay the foundation for a violent attack against White's King. The plan, however, fails, as it always must in such cases, because Black's development is backward, and consequently his pieces are not properly placed.
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 13. P - K R 3              O - O

blocks.text: 17. O - O                  P x P        18. Kt - Q 5 !
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 17. O - O                  P x P        18. Kt - Q 5 !

blocks.text: A simple move, which destroys Black's plan utterly. Black will now have no concerted action of his pieces, and, as his Pawns are all weak, he will sooner or later lose them.
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 17. O - O                  P x P        18. Kt - Q 5 !

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 17. O - O                  P x P        18. Kt - Q 5 !
GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 17. O - O                  P x P        18. Kt - Q 5 !

blocks.text: {219} The fact that he has to exchange Queens when he is a Pawn behind shows that Black's game is lost.
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 17. O - O                  P x P        18. Kt - Q 5 !

blocks.text: 21. Kt x Q                 B x Kt        22. B x B                  B - B 3        23. Q R - Q 1              B x Kt
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 17. O - O                  P x P        18. Kt - Q 5 !

blocks.text: The Knight was too threatening. But now the ending brought about is one in which the Bishop is stronger than the Knight; which makes Black's plight a desperate one. The game has no further interest, and it is only because of its value as a study of this variation of the Petroff that I have given it. Black was able to fight it out until the sixtieth move on account of some poor play on White's part. The rest of the moves are given merely as a matter of form.
blocks.section_path: GAME 10. PETROFF DEFENCE > 17. O - O                  P x P        18. Kt - Q 5 !

blocks.text: 24. R x B                  K - Kt 2        25. B - B 4                R - Kt 3        26. R - K 1                K - B 3        27. P - B 4                Kt - K 3        28. P x P ch               P x P        29. R - B 1 ch             K - K 2        30. R - Kt 4               R - K Kt 1        31. R - B 5                R - B 3        32. P - K R 4              K R - Q B 1        33. P x P                  R - B 4        34. B x Kt                 P x B        35. R x R                  R x R        36. P - Kt 6               K - B 1        37. R - Q B 4              R - Q R 4   {220}        38. P - R 4                K - Kt 2        39. R - B 6                R - Q 4        40. R - B 7 ch             K x P        41. R x P                  R - Q 8 ch        42. K - R 2                P - Q 4

P - Kt 7               R x P        60. P - R 7                R - Kt 3 ch        61. K - B 5                Resigns.

blocks.text: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: (St. Petersburg, 1914)
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: White: J. R. Capablanca. Black: D. Janowski.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             Kt - Q B 3         3. B - Kt 5               P - Q R 3         4. B x Kt                 Q P x B         5. Kt - B 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: I played this move after having discussed it with Alechin on several occasions. Alechin considered it, at the time, superior to P - Q 4, which is generally played. He played it himself later on in the Tournament, in one of his games against Dr. E. Lasker, and obtained the superior game, which he only lost through a blunder.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ
GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 5. ........               B - Q B 4

blocks.text: P - B 3 is probably the best move in this position. I do not like the text move.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 5. ........               B - Q B 4

blocks.text: 6. P - Q 3                B - K Kt 5         7. B - K 3                B x B
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 6. P - Q 3                B - K Kt 5         7. B - K 3                B x B

blocks.text: This opens the K B file for White, and also reinforces his centre, but Black naturally did not want to make a second move with this Bishop.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 6. P - Q 3                B - K Kt 5         7. B - K 3                B x B

blocks.text: 8. P x B                  Q - K 2         9. O - O                  O - O - O
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 8. P x B                  Q - K 2         9. O - O                  O - O - O

blocks.text: Bold play, typical of Janowski. {222}
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 8. P x B                  Q - K 2         9. O - O                  O - O - O

blocks.text: 10. Q - K 1                Kt - R 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 10. Q - K 1                Kt - R 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 10. Q - K 1                Kt - R 3

blocks.text: The problem for White now is to advance his Q Kt P to Kt 5 as fast as he can. If he plays P - Q Kt 4 at once, Black simply takes it. If he plays first P - Q R 3 and then P - Q Kt 4, he will still have to protect his Q Kt P before he can go on and play P - Q R 4 and P - Kt 5. As a matter of fact White played a rather unusual move, but one which, under the circumstances, was the best, since after it he could at once play P - Q Kt 4 and then P - Q R 4 and P - Kt 5.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 10. Q - K 1                Kt - R 3

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 10. Q - K 1                Kt - R 3

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 80/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 10. Q - K 1                Kt - R 3

blocks.text: 11. R - Kt 1 !             P - B 3        12. P - Kt 4               Kt - B 2        13. P - Q R 4              B x Kt
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 10. Q - K 1                Kt - R 3

blocks.text: He simplifies, hoping to lighten White's attack, which will have to be conducted practically with only the heavy pieces on the board. He may have also done it in order to play Kt - Kt 4 and K 3. {223}
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 10. Q - K 1                Kt - R 3

blocks.text: 14. R x B
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 14. R x B

blocks.text: Taking with the Pawn would have opened a possibility for a counter attack.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 14. R x B
GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 14. ........               P - Q Kt 3

blocks.text: He is forced to this in order to avoid the breaking up of his Queen's side Pawns. The only alternative would have been P - Q Kt 4; which on the face of it looks bad.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 14. ........               P - Q Kt 3

blocks.text: 15. P - Kt 5               B P x P        16. P x P                  P - Q R 4        17. Kt - Q 5               Q - B 4        18. P - B 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 14. ........               P - Q Kt 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 14. ........               P - Q Kt 3

blocks.text: The White Knight is now a tower of strength. Behind it White will be able to prepare an attack, which will begin with P - Q 4, to drive away the Black Queen and thus leave himself free to play P - B 5. There is only one thing to take care of and that {224} is to prevent Black from sacrificing the Rook for the Knight and a Pawn.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 14. ........               P - Q Kt 3
GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 14. ........               P - Q Kt 3

blocks.text: Had White on his 19th move played K R - B 1 instead of R - B 2, Black could have played now instead of the text move, R x Kt; K P x R, Q x P ch; followed by Kt - B 4 with a winning game.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 14. ........               P - Q Kt 3

blocks.text: 21. R - Q 1                K - Kt 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 21. R - Q 1                K - Kt 2

blocks.text: It would have been better for Black to play K - Q 1. The text move loses very rapidly.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 21. R - Q 1                K - Kt 2

blocks.text: 22. P - Q 4                Q - Q 3        23. R - B 2                P x P        24. P x P                  Kt - B 5        25. P - B 5                Kt x Kt        26. P x Kt                 Q x Q P        27. P - B 6 ch             K - Kt 1        28. P x R                  Q x P (Q 2)        29. P - Q 5                R - K 1        30. P - Q 6                P x P        31. Q - B 6                Resigns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 21. R - Q 1                K - Kt 2
GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 21. R - Q 1                K - Kt 2
GAME 11. RUY LOPEZ > 21. R - Q 1                K - Kt 2

blocks.text: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: (New York, 1918)
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: White: J. R. Capablanca. Black: O. Chajes.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 3         2. P - Q 4                P - Q 4         3. Kt - Q B 3             Kt - K B 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 81/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 4. B - Q 3

blocks.text: Not the most favoured move, but a perfectly natural developing one, and consequently it cannot be bad.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 4. B - Q 3
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 4. B - Q 3

blocks.text: P - Q B 4 is generally played in this case instead of the text move.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 4. B - Q 3

blocks.text: 5. Kt x P                 Q Kt - Q 2         6. Kt x Kt ch             Kt x Kt         7. Kt - B 3               B - K 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 4. B - Q 3

blocks.text: [Illustration] {226}
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 4. B - Q 3
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 8. Q - K 2

blocks.text: This is played to prevent P - Q Kt 3, followed by B - Kt 2, which is the general form of development for Black in this variation. If Black now plays 8...P - Q Kt 3; 9. B - Kt 5 ch, B - Q 2; 10. Kt - K 5 and White obtains a considerable advantage in position.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 8. Q - K 2
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 8. ........               O - O         9. B - K Kt 5             P - K R 3

blocks.text: Of course Black could not play P - Q Kt 3 because of B x Kt, followed by Q - K 4.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 8. ........               O - O         9. B - K Kt 5             P - K R 3

blocks.text: 10. B x Kt                 B x B        11. Q - K 4                P - K Kt 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 10. B x Kt                 B x B        11. Q - K 4                P - K Kt 3

blocks.text: This weakens Black's King's side. R - K 1 was the right move.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 10. B x Kt                 B x B        11. Q - K 4                P - K Kt 3
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 12. P - K R 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 12. P - K R 4
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 12. ........               P - K 4

blocks.text: This is merely giving up a Pawn in order to come out quickly with his Q B. But as he does not obtain {227} any compensation for his Pawn, the move is bad. He should have played Q - Q 4 and tried to fight the game out that way. It might have continued thus: 13. Q - B 4, B - Kt 2; 14. Q x B P, B x P; 15. Kt x B, Q x Kt; 16. O - O - O with considerable advantage of position for White. The text move might be considered a mild form of suicide.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 12. ........               P - K 4

blocks.text: 13. P x P                  B - B 4        14. Q - K B 4              B x B        15. O - O - O              B - Kt 2        16. R x B                  Q - K 2        17. Q - B 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 12. ........               P - K 4

blocks.text: In order to keep the Black Queen from coming into the game.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 12. ........               P - K 4
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Q R - Q 1        18. K R - Q 1

blocks.text: A better plan would have been to play R - K 1, threatening P - K 6.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Q R - Q 1        18. K R - Q 1
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Q R - Q 1        18. K R - Q 1

blocks.text: Of course if B x P; Kt x B, Q x Kt; R - K 3. Black with a Pawn minus fights very hard.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 17. ........               Q R - Q 1        18. K R - Q 1
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. R - K 3

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. R - K 3

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 82/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. R - K 3

blocks.text: The Pawn had now to be defended after Black's last move, because after B x P; Kt x B, Q x Kt; {228} R - K 3, Black could now play Q - Kt 1 defending the Rook.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. R - K 3
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4

blocks.text: White's plan now is to _fix_ the Queen's side in order to be able to manoeuvre freely on the other side, where he has the advantage of material.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4

blocks.text: Black sees that he now stands in his best defensive position, and therefore waits for White to show how he intends to break through. He notices, of course, that the White Knight is in the way of the K B P, which cannot advance to K B 4 to defend, or support rather, the Pawn at K 5. {229}
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4

blocks.text: 28. P - Q Kt 3             K - B 1        29. K - Q 3                K - Kt 1        30. R - Q 6                Q - B 1        31. R - Q 5                Q - K 3        32. P - K Kt 4             K - B 1        33. Q - B 4                K - Kt 1        34. Q - K 4                K - B 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4

blocks.text: Black persists in waiting for developments. He sees that if P - K R 5, P x P; P x P, the Queen goes to R 6, and White will have to face serious difficulties. In this situation White decides that the only course is to bring his King to K Kt 3, so as to defend the squares K R 3 and K Kt 4, where the Black Queen might otherwise become a source of annoyance.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4

blocks.text: 35. K - K 2                K - Kt 1        36. K - B 1                K - B 1        37. K - Kt 2               K - Kt 1        38. K - Kt 3               K - B 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4

blocks.text: Now that he has completed his march with the King, White is ready to advance.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 21. ........               P - Q B 4        22. K - B 2                P - Kt 3        23. P - R 4

blocks.text: 39. P - K R 5              P x P
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 39. P - K R 5              P x P

blocks.text: 39...P - K Kt 4 would be answered by Q - B 5, with a winning game.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 39. P - K R 5              P x P

blocks.text: 40. P x P                  Q - K 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 40. P x P                  Q - K 2

blocks.text: Against K - Kt 1; White would play Q - Kt 4, practically forcing the exchange of Queens, after which White would have little trouble in winning the ending, since Black's Bishop could not do much damage in the resulting position.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 40. P x P                  Q - K 2

blocks.text: 41. Q - B 5                K - Kt 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 41. Q - B 5                K - Kt 1

blocks.text: Black overlooks the force of 42 R - Q 7. His best defence was R - Q 1; against which White could either advance the King or play Kt - R 4, threatening Kt - Kt 6 ch.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 41. Q - B 5                K - Kt 1

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 41. Q - B 5                K - Kt 1

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 83/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 41. Q - B 5                K - Kt 1

blocks.text: 42. R - Q7                 B x P ch
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 42. R - Q7                 B x P ch
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 42. R - Q7                 B x P ch

blocks.text: This loses a piece, but Black's position was altogether hopeless.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 42. R - Q7                 B x P ch

blocks.text: 43. K - Kt 4               Q - B 3        44. Kt x B                 Q - Kt 2 ch        45. K - B 4                Resigns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 42. R - Q7                 B x P ch

blocks.text: The interest of this game centres mainly on the opening and on the march of the White King during the final stage of the game. It is an instance of the King becoming a fighting piece, even while the Queens are still on the board.
blocks.section_path: GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 42. R - Q7                 B x P ch
GAME 12. FRENCH DEFENCE > 42. R - Q7                 B x P ch

blocks.text: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: (New York, 1918)
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: White: J. S. Morrison. Black: J. R. Capablanca.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: 1. P - K 4                P - K 4         2. Kt - K B 3             Kt - Q B 3         3. B - Kt 5               P - Q 3         4. Kt - B 3               B - Q 2         5. P - Q 4                P x P         6. Kt x P                 P - K Kt 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: In this form of defence of the Ruy Lopez the development of the K B via Kt 2 is, I think, of great importance. The Bishop at Kt 2 exerts great pressure along the long diagonal. At the same time the position of the Bishop and Pawns in front of the King, once it is Castled, is one of great defensive strength. Therefore, in this form of development, the Bishop, {232} we might say, exerts its maximum strength (Compare this note with the one in the Capablanca-Burn game at San Sebastian, page 197.)
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ

blocks.text: 7. Kt - B 3               B - Kt 2         8. B - Kt 5               Kt - B 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 7. Kt - B 3               B - Kt 2         8. B - Kt 5               Kt - B 3

blocks.text: Of course not K Kt - K 2; because of Kt - Q 5. The alternative would have been P - B 3; to be followed by K Kt - K 2; but in this position it is preferable to have the Kt at K B 3.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 7. Kt - B 3               B - Kt 2         8. B - Kt 5               Kt - B 3

blocks.text: 9. Q - Q 2                P - K R 3        10. B - K R 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 9. Q - Q 2                P - K R 3        10. B - K R 4

blocks.text: An error of judgment. White wants to keep the Knight pinned, but it was more important to prevent Black from Castling immediately. B - K B 4 would have done this.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 9. Q - Q 2                P - K R 3        10. B - K R 4
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 10. ........               O - O        11. O - O - O

blocks.text: Bold play, but again faulty judgment, unless he intended to play to win or lose, throwing safety to the winds. The Black Bishop at Kt 2 becomes a very powerful attacking piece. The strategical disposition of the Black pieces is now far superior to White's, therefore it will be Black who will take the offensive.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 10. ........               O - O        11. O - O - O
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 11. ........               R - K 1        12. K R - K 1
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 11. ........               R - K 1        12. K R - K 1

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 11. ........               R - K 1        12. K R - K 1

blocks.text: White wanted to keep his Q R on the open file, and consequently brings over
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 11. ........               R - K 1        12. K R - K 1

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 11. ........               R - K 1        12. K R - K 1

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 84/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 11. ........               R - K 1        12. K R - K 1

blocks.text: his other Rook to the centre to defend his K P, which Black threatened to win by P - K Kt 4, followed by Kt x P.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 11. ........               R - K 1        12. K R - K 1
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 12. ........               P - Kt 4 !

blocks.text: Now that the K R is in the centre, Black can safely advance, since, in order to attack on the King's side, White would have to shift his Rooks, which he cannot do so long as Black keeps up the pressure in the centre.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 12. ........               P - Kt 4 !

blocks.text: 13. B - Kt 3               Kt - K R 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 13. B - Kt 3               Kt - K R 4

blocks.text: Uncovering the Bishop, which now acts along the long diagonal, and at the same time preventing P - K 5, which would be answered by Kt x B; P x Kt, Kt x P; etc., winning a Pawn.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 13. B - Kt 3               Kt - K R 4

blocks.text: 14. Kt - Q 5               P - R 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 14. Kt - Q 5               P - R 3

blocks.text: Black drives the Bishop away so as to _unpin_ his pieces and be able to manoeuvre freely. {234}
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 14. Kt - Q 5               P - R 3
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 15. B - Q 3                B - K 3

blocks.text: Preparing the onslaught. Black's pieces begin to bear against the King's position.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 15. B - Q 3                B - K 3
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 16. P - B 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 16. P - B 3

blocks.text: With the last move White not only blocks the action of Black's K B, but he also aims at placing his Bishop at Q Kt 1 and his Queen at Q B 2, and then advancing his K P, to check at K R 7.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 16. P - B 3
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 16. ........               P - B 4 !

blocks.text: Initiating an attack to which there is no reply, and which has for its ultimate object either the winning of the White Q B or cutting it off from the game. (Compare this game with the Winter-Capablanca game at Hastings.)
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 16. ........               P - B 4 !

blocks.text: 17. P - K R 4              P - B 5
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 17. P - K R 4              P - B 5

blocks.text: The Bishop is now out of action. White naturally counter attacks violently against the seemingly {235} exposed position of the Black King, and, with very good judgment, even offers the Bishop.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 17. P - K R 4              P - B 5

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 17. P - K R 4              P - B 5

blocks.text: 18. P x P !                P x P !
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 18. P x P !                P x P !

blocks.text: Taking the Bishop would be dangerous, if not actually bad, while the text move accomplishes Black's object, which is to put the Bishop out of action.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 18. P x P !                P x P !
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 19. R - R 1                B - B 2        20. K - Kt 1

blocks.text: This move unquestionably loses time. Since he would have to retire his Bishop to R 2 sooner or later, he might have done it immediately. It is doubtful, however, if at this stage of the game it would be possible for White to save the game.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 19. R - R 1                B - B 2        20. K - Kt 1

blocks.text: 20. ........               Kt - K 4        21. Kt x Kt                R x Kt
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 20. ........               Kt - K 4        21. Kt x Kt                R x Kt

blocks.text: It was difficult to decide which way to retake. I {236} took with the Rook in order to have it prepared for a possible attack against the King.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 20. ........               Kt - K 4        21. Kt x Kt                R x Kt

blocks.text: 22. B - R 2                Kt - B 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 22. B - R 2                Kt - B 3

blocks.text: Now that the White Bishop has been driven back, Black wants to get rid of
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 22. B - R 2                Kt - B 3

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 22. B - R 2                Kt - B 3

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 85/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 22. B - R 2                Kt - B 3

blocks.text: White's strongly posted Knight at Q 5, which blocks the attack of the Bishop at B 2. It may be said that the Knight at Q 5 is the key to White's defence.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 22. B - R 2                Kt - B 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 22. B - R 2                Kt - B 3
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 23. P - Kt 3

blocks.text: White strives not only to have play for his Bishop, but also he wants to break up Black's Pawns in order to counter-attack. The alternative would have been 23 Kt x Kt ch, Q x Kt; and Black would be threatening R - R 4, and also Q - K 3. The student should notice that Black's drawback in all this is the fact that he is playing minus the services of his Q R. It is this fact that makes it possible for White to hold out longer. {237}
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 23. P - Kt 3

blocks.text: 23. ........               Kt x P        24. B x Kt                 R x B        25. P x P                  P - B 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 23. P - Kt 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 23. P - Kt 3
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 26. Kt - K 3

blocks.text: Kt - Kt 4 was the alternative, but in any event White could not resist the attack. I leave it to the reader to work this out for himself, as the variations are so numerous that they would take up too much space.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 26. Kt - K 3

blocks.text: 26. ........               Q - R 4        27. P - B 4                Q x Q        28. R x Q                  P x P        29. Kt - Kt 4              B - Kt 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 26. Kt - K 3

blocks.text: This forces the King to the corner, where he will be in a mating net.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 26. Kt - K 3

blocks.text: 30. K - R 1                Q R - K 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 30. K - R 1                Q R - K 1

blocks.text: Now at last the Q R enters into the game and soon the battle is over.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 30. K - R 1                Q R - K 1
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 31. P - R 3

blocks.text: If R x P, R - K 8 ch; R - Q 1, R (K 1) - K 7. {238}
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 31. P - R 3

blocks.text: 31. ........               R - K 8 ch        32. R x R                  R x R ch        33. K - R 2                B - B 2        34. K - Kt 3               P - Q 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 31. P - R 3

blocks.text: the quickest way to finish the game.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 31. P - R 3

blocks.text: 35. B x P                  P x P ch        36. K - Kt 4               P - B 6        37. P x P                  R - K 5 ch        38. P - B 4                R x P ch        39. K - R 5                R x B        40. R - Q 8 ch             K - R 2        41. R - Q 7                B - K 3             Resigns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 31. P - R 3

blocks.text: A very lively game.
blocks.section_path: GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 31. P - R 3
GAME 13. RUY LOPEZ > 31. P - R 3

blocks.text: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: (New York, 1918)
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: White: F. J. Marshall. Black: J. R. Capablanca.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED

blocks.text: 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 86/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4

blocks.text: 2. Kt - K B 3             Kt - K B 3         3. P - B 4                P - K 3         4. Kt - B 3               Q Kt - Q 2         5. B - Kt 5               B - K 2         6. P - K 3                O - O         7. R - B 1                P - B 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4

blocks.text: This is one of the oldest systems of defence against the Queen's Gambit. I had played it before in this Tournament against Kostic, and no doubt Marshall expected it. At times I change my defences, {239} or rather systems of defence; on the other hand, during a Tournament, if one of them has given me good results, I generally play it all the time.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4

blocks.text: 8. Q - B 2                P x P         9. B x P                  Kt - Q 4        10. B x B                  Q x B        11. O - O                  Kt x Kt        12. Q x Kt                 P - Q Kt 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4

blocks.text: This is the key to this system of defence. Having simplified the game considerably by a series of exchanges, Black will now develop his Q B along the long diagonal without having created any apparent weakness. The proper development of the Q B is Black's greatest problem in the Queen's Gambit.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 1. P - Q 4                P - Q 4

blocks.text: 13. P - K 4                B - Kt 2        14. K R - K 1              K R - Q 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 13. P - K 4                B - Kt 2        14. K R - K 1              K R - Q 1

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 13. P - K 4                B - Kt 2        14. K R - K 1              K R - Q 1

blocks.text: The developing stage can now be said to be complete on both sides. The opening is over and the middle-game begins. White, as is generally the case, has {240} obtained the centre. Black, on the other hand, is entrenched in his first three ranks, and if given time will post his Q R at Q B 1 and his Knight at K B 3, and finally play P - Q B 4, in order to break up White's centre and give full action to the Black Bishop posted at Q Kt 2. In this game White attempts to anticipate that plan by initiating an advance on the centre, which, when carefully analysed, is truly an attack against Black's K P.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 13. P - K 4                B - Kt 2        14. K R - K 1              K R - Q 1
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 15. P - Q 5                Kt - B 4 !

blocks.text: Against Kostic in a previous game I had played Kt - B 1. It was carelessness on my part, but Marshall believed differently, otherwise he would not have played this variation, since, had he analysed this move, he would, I think, have realised that Black would obtain an excellent game. Black now threatens not only B P x P; but also Kt x P; followed by B P x P. The position is very interesting and full of possibilities.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 15. P - Q 5                Kt - B 4 !

blocks.text: [Illustration] {241}
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 15. P - Q 5                Kt - B 4 !

blocks.text: 16. P x K P                Kt x P (K 3)        17. B x Kt                 Q x B
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 16. P x K P                Kt x P (K 3)        17. B x Kt                 Q x B

blocks.text: played under the impression that White had to lose time in defending his Q R P, when I could play P - Q B 4, obtaining a very superior game. But, as will be seen, my opponent had quite a little surprise for me.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 16. P x K P                Kt x P (K 3)        17. B x Kt                 Q x B
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. Kt - Q 4 !

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. Kt - Q 4 !
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. ........               Q - K 4 !

blocks.text: Of course, if 18...Q x R P; 19 R - R 1 would win the Queen. The text move is probably the only satisfactory move in the position. The obvious move would have been Q - Q 2 to defend the Q B P, and then would have come 19 Kt - B 5, P - B 3; 20 Q - K Kt 3 (threatening Q R - Q 1), K - R 1; 21 Q R - Q 1, Q - K B 2; 22 P - K R 4, with a tremendous advantage in position. The text move, on the other hand, assures Black an even game at
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. ........               Q - K 4 !

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. ........               Q - K 4 !

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 87/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. ........               Q - K 4 !

blocks.text: the very least, as will soon be seen. {242}
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 18. ........               Q - K 4 !

blocks.text: 19. Kt x P                 Q x Q        20. R x Q                  R - Q 7        21. R - Kt 1
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 19. Kt x P                 Q x Q        20. R x Q                  R - Q 7        21. R - Kt 1

blocks.text: A very serious error of judgment. White is under the impression that he has the better game, because he is a Pawn ahead, but that is not so. The powerful position of the Black Rook at Q 7 fully compensates Black for the Pawn minus. Besides, the Bishop is better with Rooks than the Knight (see pages 48-56, where the relative values of the Knight and Bishop are compared), and, as already stated, with Pawns on both sides of the board the Bishop is superior because of its long range. Incidentally, this ending will demonstrate the great power of the Bishop. White's best chance was to take a draw at once, thus. 21 Kt - K 7 ch K - B 1; 22 R - B 7 R - K 1 (not B x P; because P - B 3 would give White the best of it); 23 R x B (best; not Kt - Kt 6 ch, because of B P x Kt; followed by R x K P), R x Kt; 24 R - Kt 8 ch, R - K 1; 25 R x R ch, K x R, and with proper play White will draw.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 19. Kt x P                 Q x Q        20. R x Q                  R - Q 7        21. R - Kt 1

blocks.text: It is curious that, although a Pawn ahead, White is the one who is always in danger. It is only now, after seeing this analysis, that the value of Black's 18th move Q - K 4 can be fully appreciated.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 19. Kt x P                 Q x Q        20. R x Q                  R - Q 7        21. R - Kt 1
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 21. ........               R - K 1

blocks.text: With this powerful move Black begins, against White's centre, an assault which will soon be shifted against {243} the King itself. White is afraid to play 22 P - B 3 because of P - B 4.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 21. ........               R - K 1

blocks.text: 22. P - K 5                P - K Kt 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 22. P - K 5                P - K Kt 4

blocks.text: To prevent P - B 4. The White Knight is practically pinned, because he does not dare move on account of R x K P.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 22. P - K 5                P - K Kt 4

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 22. P - K 5                P - K Kt 4
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 23. P - K R 4

blocks.text: This is a sequel to the previous move. White expects to disrupt Black's Pawns, and thus make them weak.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 23. P - K R 4
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 23. ........               P x P

blocks.text: Though doubled and isolated this Pawn exercises enormous pressure. Black now threatens R - K 3; to be followed by R - Kt 3 and P - R 6 and R 7 at the proper time.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 23. ........               P x P
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 24. R - K 1

blocks.text: White cannot stand the slow death any longer. {244} He sees danger everywhere, and wants to avert it by giving up his Queen's side Pawns, expecting to regain his fortunes later on by taking the initiative on the King's side.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 24. R - K 1
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 24. ........               R - K 3 !

blocks.text: Much better than taking Pawns. This forces White to defend the Knight with the Rook at K 1, because of the threat R - Kt 3.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 24. ........               R - K 3 !

blocks.text: 25. R (K1) - Q B 1         K - Kt 2
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 25. R (K1) - Q B 1         K - Kt 2

blocks.text: Preparatory to R - Kt 3. The game is going to be decided on the King's side, and it is the isolated double Pawn that will supply the finishing touch.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 25. R (K1) - Q B 1         K - Kt 2

blocks.text: 26. P - Q Kt 4             P - Kt 4
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 26. P - Q Kt 4             P - Kt 4

blocks.text: To prevent P - Kt 5, defending the Knight and liberating the Rooks.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 26. P - Q Kt 4             P - Kt 4

blocks.text: 02/10/2025, 11:48 gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 26. P - Q Kt 4             P - Kt 4

blocks.text: https://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/33870/pg33870.txt 88/95
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 26. P - Q Kt 4             P - Kt 4
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 27. P - R 3                R - Kt 3        28. K - B 1                R - R 7

blocks.text: [Illustration] {245}
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 27. P - R 3                R - Kt 3        28. K - B 1                R - R 7

blocks.text: Notice the remarkable position of the pieces. White cannot move anything without incurring some loss. His best chance would have been to play 29 P - K 6, but that would only have prolonged the game, which is lost in any case.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 27. P - R 3                R - Kt 3        28. K - B 1                R - R 7

blocks.text: 29. K - Kt 1               P - R 6        30. P - Kt 3               P - Q R 3
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 29. K - Kt 1               P - R 6        30. P - Kt 3               P - Q R 3

blocks.text: Again forcing White to move and to lose something thereby, as all his pieces are tied up.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 29. K - Kt 1               P - R 6        30. P - Kt 3               P - Q R 3

blocks.text: [Illustration]
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 29. K - Kt 1               P - R 6        30. P - Kt 3               P - Q R 3

blocks.text: 31. P - K 6                R x K P
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 31. P - K 6                R x K P

blocks.text: Not even now can White move the Knight because of P - R 7 ch; K x P, R - R 3 ch; K - Kt 1, R - R 8 mate.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 31. P - K 6                R x K P
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.text: If 33 P - Kt 5, P - R 7 ch; 34 K - R 1, R x Kt; 35 R x R, R x P, winning easily. {246}
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.text: 33. ........               R - Q 3        34. Kt - K 7               R (Q3) - Q 7        35. Kt - B 5 ch            K - B 3        36. Kt - R 4               K - Kt 4        37. Kt - B 5               R - Kt 7 ch        38. K - B 1                P - R 7        39. P - B 4 ch             K x B P        40. Resigns.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.text: An ending worth very careful study.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3
GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.text: Notes
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.text: [1] The value of the initiative is explained in section 20, p. 77.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.text: [2] See page 37.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.text: [5] This position is elaborated under Example 50 (p. 80.).
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.text: [6] We give, from now on, games and notes, so that the student may familiarise himself with the many and varied considerations that constantly are borne in mind by the Chess Master. We must take it for granted that the student has already reached a stage where, while not being able fully to understand every move, yet he can derive benefit from any discussion with regard to them.
blocks.section_path: GAME 14. QUEEN'S GAMBIT DECLINED > 32. P - Kt 4               R - R 3        33. P - B 3

blocks.text: [7] A "hole" in chess parlance has come to mean a defect in Pawn formation which allows the opponent to establish his forces in wedge formation or otherwise without the possibility of dislodging him by Pawn moves. Thus, in the following diagram, Black has two holes at K B 3 and K R 3, where White forces, e.g. a Kt or B, could establish themselves, supported by pieces or
